author: Slow Hand
content:
I'd like to say thank you to @everyone here. It's no overstatement to say that you *are* this server and the reason for it's success.

author: JakeTB
content:
Hey all. Just wanted to say how much I appreciate this community and attest to the quality of conversation here.

I put in my resignation notice at the day job today, and will be transitioning to music full-time in May. I genuinely don’t believe I could have done it without this place. You all challenge me in the best ways, and have helped me grow tremendously as a person and a professional.

I still don’t have it all sorted out, and I’m still fervently pursuing mentorship in any form I can find, but for now the work is paying the bills; something I thought I’d never be able to say.

Thank you all for being generous with your hard-earned wisdom. It really does make a difference.

(Sorry, got a bit sappy there 😅)

author: Slow Hand
content:
Sooooo.... It's come to my attention that not everyone has an internal monologue. A voice in their head. This is kind of wild to me. Supposedly as many as 50% of people don't have an inner monologue. 

It never occurred to me that people wouldn't, but I guess I shouldn't be surprised. My mind's eye is pretty lo-res, while some of my friends have the ability to visualize very detailed imagery in their heads.

Now I'm curious. Who here has an internal monologue and who does not?

Gimme a 👍 if you do have an internal monologue.

author: chrissorem
content:
Story time:  yesterday I received a text from a manager I supposedly know. He Said I have an artist that has a jazz album that needs mixed. He asked me can you text him? I thought to myself that’s not normally how this goes but sure..  so I texted and within an instant, he called me. He said.” did you look me up?” I said no I just texted you like I was asked. He said.” you should look me up.” he proceeded to tell me  he’s been signed to major label  for 25 years. Supposedly Warner brothers and followed with they gave him $600 to mix this album which then I said I’m sorry but I can’t help you.. he said “send me a number of someone who can mix a jazz album.” I sent him to a friend who I know it was hurting for work.. then he text me back about five minutes later and said this guy never mixed a jazz album before. Send me  somebody who mixed a jazz album preferably over 40. I sent him Al Schmitt’s contact and he responded to me. “All has  been dead for several years get with it man.”

there’s nothing to be learned here.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok Long Post alert, but touches on a few things we harp on around here. 

So my little bro is in town- we made dinner for one of his oldest friends who just moved to town with his wife. He’s a fantastic mandolin player and his wife is a singer/songwriter. 

Of course I did the ol’ studio walk through, listening to all the tunes on the ear calibration playlist, then let them play some of their own favs. Of course they’re blown away and have never heard music like this etc. 

But to drive the point home I show them a song @Rollmottle and I turned around in just over 24 hours. “The reason for the speakers & treatment etc is so we can make decisions quickly blah blah blah.”  I pull up the session and we listen through and they’re loving it- but I’m noticing it doesn’t have the 3D thing that all the other music we’ve been listening to has. 

Then I show them the mastered version. An mp3. It’s louder and better sounding and all, until the first BGV stack hits… then it’s IMMERSIVE. We listened to the whole thing again just to enjoy the magic and notice all the ways the master improved it. So far beyond zapping resonances and making it loud, @Rollmottle made it sound… important. Made *me* sound like a good mixer. 

It was heavier lifting for him cause I didn’t have the benefit of time for fresh ears or to detail the vocal the way I normally would. Also had the good fortune of having @Ross Fortune on speed dial and on GMT to give it a listen at 5am PST. 

I’d you’re curious, or dubious, I’ll DM files so you can hear what I’m talking about. 

TL;DR: monitoring matters, fresh perspective matters. Don’t produce mix *and* master your own shit.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: “Nobody tells this to people who are beginners, I wish someone told me. All of us who do creative work, we get into it because we have good taste. But there is this gap. For the first couple years you make stuff, it’s just not that good. It’s trying to be good, it has potential, but it’s not. But your taste, the thing that got you into the game, is still killer. And your taste is why your work disappoints you. A lot of people never get past this phase, they quit. Most people I know who do interesting, creative work went through years of this. We know our work doesn’t have this special thing that we want it to have. We all go through this. And if you are just starting out or you are still in this phase, you gotta know its normal and the most important thing you can do is do a lot of work. Put yourself on a deadline so that every week you will finish one story. It is only by going through a volume of work that you will close that gap, and your work will be as good as your ambitions. And I took longer to figure out how to do this than anyone I’ve ever met. It’s gonna take awhile. It’s normal to take awhile. You’ve just gotta fight your way through.” - Ira Glass

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Re; Brauer workshop

-First 2 days were nothing technical, the 1st conversation he brought up was about TM and how meditation in general has helped him.
-Everything is feel-based, most technical Q's for the first 2 and a half days got the same reply: "It doesn't matter to me, i don't care what the thing is long as it feels good". 
-MHB actually seems to leave the planet while he's mixing, it's wild how immediate he gets into that space. Seemed to go way past "i love mixing and here's all the reasons i'm the shit" and it was inspiring to see the ego leave the equation. His decades of experience are playing directly into his ability to access the story of the song and present it in a compelling, live-feeling way. He mixes from inside the song and performs. Well, he does discovery, then shapes the sounds, then performs just about everything on faders.
-The biggest wake up call to me is that a lot of moves i've made on mixes did not have a good reason behind them. So continuing to ask "why" as I work is gonna be important, because I have to start catching myself and adjusting when the answer to "why" is "because someone said this preset is cool" or "because this is what I do to a vocal/guitar/drums". I feel music very deeply, it's why i got into this, but I feel like i've been poisoned against trusting that instinct and convinced that what we do is a technical job. I'm done being an observer of the art, i want to be bold.
-It's critical to build trust with clients right away, you can't assume anything in what they understand about how you feel. Telling them you love the song and you're excited to mix it is important, and never blaming production/artist/anything else for the mix being less than what it should be. never okay to say "i did my best", because that gives you an out and implies somebody else could do it better
-Therefore, you must believe when you sit down to mix that nobody is gonna interpret this song better than you.
-Generally i'm skeptical to just take on someone else's "method" and start operating in that space just becuase of the success they've had with it. Putting this week into practice is going to mean using his template to get reps in, listening and feeling and interacting in a new way and letting my brain "level up", if you will, then zooming out and making it my own.


I can distill this more and want to share about a couple other specifics, but I just realized I grabbed someone else's notebook by mistake when I left on the last day so I'll need to have them mail mine back to me.

author: chrissorem
content:
Here is where we are at so far: O’Flaherty is known for his unorthodox and borderline mystical approach to mastering. While some engineers rely on meters, graphs, and measurable science, Ruairí prefers to keep things mysterious under the hood — very mysterious. No one really knows what’s going on in the session file… including Ruairí. And that’s the point.

Most of his day is spent clicking on vaguely psychedelic images of your waveform and nodding slowly. Sometimes he zooms in, sometimes he just stares at the phase scope like it owes him money. Occasionally, he’ll touch a knob — but never the same one twice.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I was having a conversation with a buddy of mine that has a child with Cerebral Palsy a while back. I’d said that it must be challenging, and he told me a story I’ll never forget. He said “you know that old bit about being able to go to a party and dump your most challenging life issue in the middle of the room?” (I didn’t)
“Basically everyone goes to a party and you’re allowed to leave your biggest challenge there, as long as you leave with someone else’s biggest challenge. And at the end of the night everyone realizes they’d rather go home with the challenge they came with after seeing everybody else’s”. 
The lesson of that has really stuck with me. Our lives tend to be better than we realize once we’ve seen what others ACTUALLY have to deal with, not just the tip of the iceberg they show to the world.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
I've had certain partners that are easier to deal with than others with this kind of thing for sure, and being with someone who actually understands these things really helps, but at the end of the day no one wants to be with someone who's grinding 100% of the time. There's more to life than that, and whats the point of being in a relationship if you never see the other person. I also get the working in music/freelance lifestyle, and sometimes its hard to even want to do fun things outside of it when you're so focused on this thing that really excites you that also is your livelyhood.

Its such a hard thing to get right and in my experience with certain partners, its been an ongoing arguement, even in the past when i've had salary jobs and a very predictable schedule. So i'm not sure it goes away by making your life more regimented. I think the only answer here is being super open and radically honest about everything. 

In my experience, letting your partner know when you've been asked to do something before you've agreed to it, makes them feel like they're a part of the thought process behind the work and less like they're just observing you living your life from the outside. Even if you were always gonna say yes to it anyway, at least they feel like they have some control and are on the same team as you. IME you just gotta go out of your way to make them feel like they're doing it all with you. They feel closer to you in a situation where they could just as easily feel like they're being pushed away. I'm not sure what way you've went about it, thats just my experience. If you're living with your partner you kinda have to see yourselves as the same person working toward the same thing, as opposed to two individuals with their own lives.

Also going out of your way to be spontaneous and do something fun and/or stupid like you're teenagers when things arent as busy goes a long way when things are.

author: popaganda.
content:
You’re gut’s probably right about this situation, but I also feel like you’re saying “everything isn’t the way I want it to be right now so I’m gonna bail.” Collaboration is really hard and nobody gets it 💯 their way, and it sounds like you feel like your efforts are wasted if the aesthetic is fucked. 
But no effort towards making good music is a waste. If that were the case me and a lot of the folks here would be complete losers, but we’re not. We’re actually better for having worked on things that we’d never share willingly.
Is this really a reason to bail? I’m not saying it isn’t. But aesthetics are really subjective. Are you saying your finger’s on the pulse of your generation’s aesthetic taste? Is there room for differences? Also, it sounds like your friend wrote the songs and is the frontman, and you are producing, playing bass, and mixing. Why are you so attached to the visual aspect of it when your role is more support rather than the face of the project?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Loving your job 80% of the time is a phenomenal, compared to the general public. 

One thing I’m amazed by working with Cian & Rollmottle is their endless capacity for positivity during a project. No matter how shitty my delivery or communication, they approach things with a smile and a sense of humor. I’ve literally never heard either of them complain. I thought commiserating about shitty aspects of a gig was a part of professionalism, but they have me rethinking things. 

In my own projects, when I approach clients with patience and curiosity, I find that not only are they happier faster, I’m happier the whole time. It’s SO MUCH EASIER to say “let’s try it” than to say “here’s why that’s not a good idea.” I find I learn a lot that way too. 

In any case, going back in to fix or add only bugs me when I think I’m supposed to be done. If I can stay open, then opening a session feels a lot easier. 

So I guess my advice is: you might have fewer problem clients if you try to remember they’re not problems to solve, they’re people to serve.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Fun little chat with my old mic tech in LA. He and his wife sing together and are getting back into it. 

He’s got a vintage 67 and 269 in pristine condition, is mostly doing audio for movies now so he’s stepped out of tech work and will only send his mics to Germany to get worked on. 

That’s all preamble for this part of the story. 

He recently did a shootout on pres & compressors for his home setup. Ended up selling his vintage Neve & La2a in favor of the ORIGINAL MBOX. The first iteration that had Focusrite pres I guess? Had to buy old laptops to run ProTools 8. Has 3 rigs at his place and got ‘em all for under a $100. 

Boys & Girls, Vintage Digital is officially en vogue.

author: Josh
content:
Two years ago I said “no more rock/metal projects” 

Two weeks ago I worked on my first label gig. It was rock/metal. 

Because I’m so far removed from the genre and don’t care for most of the sonics, lyrics, or really anything about the music (generally speaking), I found my ideas stuck out in ways they never did when I was working in the genre. The band valued my input on the deeper production stuff, the lyrics, my melodies and cadences. 

It was my mission to not hate these songs, that was my ONLY goal (pessimistic, but realistic), and I ended up loving every single one of them.

author: Skyler Young
content:
I’m in a discord  with a bunch of genius indie plug-in developers where they all show their crazy dual screen setups, well designed shortcuts, pretty back end that a user will never see, flexing making their program 2% more efficient, etc. And almost none of them have released anything that anyone cares about. I am always thinking “holy shit how don’t they all see that they are simply wasting their time!”.  

The only reason I have found more success than them is because have I directed 100% of my effort towards getting my projects over the line and 0% on workflow, pretty code etc. 

BUT I have realized I am the total OPPOSITE side when it comes to music creation. And that’s probably why I haven’t yet had the success I have wanted!

 I am so guilty of always thinking about the next piece of gear or drum sample or guitar pickups that will get me “the sound I’m looking for” but I should be focusing my effort toward tangible goals like finishing 10 great songs this month or 50 great beats or whatever.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
The creator of the art will never see it as the audience sees it. Almost every artist I know would like to redo things that they've already put out in the world. There's endless stories of this phenomenon. And while we as creators and contributors try and perfect the things that we make, it's very often the imperfections and the personality of the moment that makes art unique and powerful.

Our art form is essentially about capturing moments/ time periods. Rarely do retrospective editing moves enhance that initial feeling imho

author: cian riordan
content:
"Sorry about the late night duplicate file, I did this track after six other people because I'm rushing as a team player.   I delivered as promised up front as we are all in overtime now to make it great.  *CLIENT* is happy with your work and with mine and we are all working overtime together.   Apologies also, I know there were some annoying ticks in there with some of the revised files. Still not sure why this one session did that. 

Of course I don't listen to every single file, post rendering.   We render and send 500-1000 files a month with the revisions on the 200-300 monthly songs that I do.  Team players don't ask such things on CC.  I work usually 7 days a week for 40-50 people a month, and making them happy with great masters is job #1.  Perfectionism is not a part of that process.    Software makes mistake, and that's ok.    People make mistakes and that's ok.   Mixes and masters should never aim for perfect, they should aim to connect, aim for humanity.  

Perfection is not the goal here, it's musicality and teamwork.  I'm sorry your ears suffered that horrible popping, but please, be cool. "

author: popaganda.
content: Several years ago I was on the hunt for the perfect guitar synth and landed on the VG8 from the late 90s. It was a weird box but had some amazingly responsive presets in it, nestled between random shred tones. It was awesome but I never made much music on it, and it ended up in my closet bc it was too bulky to live on my studio floor. I have to admit I felt jealous when this mk.gee wave hit and I saw 2 vg8s on the stage. I was sitting on a goldmine but I didn’t use it enough and they got there first! Been playing baritones for a long time too, fingerstyle. The lesson for me in this is that no matter what sounds are available to me, I need to be constantly re-connecting to my Why. Why do I make music? Remembering with a sense of urgency my need to express the deepest parts of myself and not just getting tossed around in a land of “shoulds,” chasing fads, second-guessing authentic ideas.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
She's sounds so great. I love her too (respectfully).

I used to be annoyed when people asked me basic or uninformed questions on music topics that I am tired of talking about. 

Then I realized that consistently explaining the basics to people that are interested is really good for my brain and work and soul.

The Nobel prize winning genius theoretical physicist Richard Feynman said the only job he would never stop doing is teaching physics to undergrads. Explaining the basics is grounding and reinforces your foundation of knowledge.

If you ever get the chance, you should show your mom how Ozone works. It would blow her mind.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Imposter syndrome is normal and good. 

Just accept it and realize that some anxiety about your abilities will continue to push you to do better work.

Find mental health strategies so it doesn't drive you insane.

People who always think they're great or have it all figured out never improve and generally start to make shitty work quickly.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
There’s a few questions there so one at a time I guess. I’m just going to answer what you asked directly, and maybe this week I can take a shot at answering what I think are the underlying themes..

**How do you approach your craft now, in terms of attention to detail**

Nothing has changed in terms of my attention to detail, everything gets the same love as it always did. The stakes for errors have gone up - when they are manufacturing 100k copies of vinyl then you have to be sure it’s error free

**Do you reject artists if they approach you to “Master my album i’ll pay you whatever you want” if you think the level of their sound might not honour your history with all these artists**

I don’t reject *anyone* who can pay my rate. I don’t vet clients on a “how will you make me look?” basis, I’m a service provider to them. There are very very occasionally mismatches where I’ll say “happy to do this but I think you’d be better served by XYZ”, an example being someone coming to me with EDM who wants really intense processing - another girl or guy steeped in that genre will serve them better

**How does it feel having a connection to these artists?**

It feels really nice to be trusted with people’s art, when someone like a St. Vincent says “yeah, this is good” it matters to me, she has great ears and taste so it feels good to hit a mark

It’s also very special to hear these things come out of the speaker for the first time - I’ll never forget hearing Nick Cave, or Taylor or Lana in the room for the first time. It’s a privilege to be trusted with their art

**but does it ever happen that you are wanting more?”**

I’m human and can be reliably trusted to do all the silly human things like being greedy, insecure, fearful etc. but every year I get a little better at living a better way, and around the music in particular my operating principles “The why” feel better and truer than they ever have

author: LAPhill
content:
I don't know why I didn't think of this sooner, but the closest parallel to the seismic shift of AI might be samples, even more so than things like digital recording or Pro Tools. When Hans Zimmer recorded an orchestra and started writing music with a DAW and showing clients mockups, nothing was ever the same. For a long time (even now!) the pencil-and-paper people griped about how it wasn't real composition. Orchestras feared that they would all be replaced by computers. But ultimately, everyone had to come to terms with the new world order and adapt. There was a period in the mid-90s through mid-late 2000s where orchestral writing was reduced to nothing more than long notes and short notes. All of the nuance was gone, because the tech couldn't handle it yet and people blamed the tech. Many mourned the loss of true orchestral writing, yearning for a by-gone era. 

But eventually, people learned to harness these new tools and they met the technology on its own terms. People are doing wildly innovative things with samples now, we've moved completely past the era of "can I make a convincing clarinet come out of my keyboard?" Orchestras and live musicians have not been replaced. Sure, the process is different than it used to be, but that's how innovations work. All of us would be living very different lives without samples of drums, guitars, orchestras, synths, etc. There will be a generation coming up where AI is already a thing, they won't have ever lived in the before-times. Just like those here who've never cut to tape. It's okay.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Hi @everyone. Here’s a quick PSA: 

If you ever see a post with a link like this on any of the server channels, *never* click on the link. It is a phishing attack that will hijack your account and then use a bot to spam the same links on every available channel that your account has access to. If you ever see anything like this DM a moderator (such as myself) immediately so that we can delete them all.

If people on our server start clicking on these links then it can cascade into a boatload of obnoxious spam very quickly.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I mean, I usually shoot for around -9LUFS. Depending on the track, I get there in different ways. (But the client never hears what I send to the ME.) Then I take off the last “make it loud” elements and send both hot and non-limited prints, so they can hear what the client approved after doing their thing. 
(Like doing measurements in your room after you get it feeling good.) 
Honestly this is mostly because certain elements behave differently when you start to squash a track. I wanna have a good guess for what’s gonna happen when Anthony smashes it through Waves L2 & send it back and charges me full price.

author: Karim
content:
This was resolved today! Sharing what I learned in case anyone encounters a similar situation:

–  Meta has an internal tool called “Oops” to address issues (like accidental bans) for friends and family.

– Access to Oops has become significantly more restricted since the pandemic because some employees began selling access to it. 

– Your best option is to connect with someone at Meta who still has direct access or knows someone who does.

– Labels (even small ones) typically have a direct line to a Meta industry representative with access. 

– Unless you personally know someone at Meta who genuinely cares about your situation, the industry rep is likely the only person with an incentive to keep music/audio folks happy. You'll just have to provide them your handle, a detailed account of what happened that they can forward to Oops, and a new email that you've never used with any Meta platform.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Ironically, my career always seems to go best when my back is up against the wall. There’s that extra gear that panic gives me that helps me lift the car off my leg or put up with Cian or do whatever else seemed impossible  at first glance. 

Once I got out of college I spent my days selling clothes to the rich and thin before I got enough music work to leave that gig. We all go through the 40 hour week of day job and 60 hour week  of music making grind at one point of our career or another. And even when you get to quit the day job, almost everyone I know in our business has gone through what i call the “Cell service rack”, where you get a couple of gigs and your rack gets filled with cool gear and then all of the sudden it’s quiet for a few months and there gets to be less gear in those racks as you sell things to make rent. It looks like the changing meter of how much cell signal you have. There’s no shame in that game. 

For better or worse, it never ends either. I know 9 figure millionaires that are like “maybe I need to get rid of the fifth house in Aspen and free up some capital”. There’s nothing wrong with proactively taking stock of your life every once in a while and re evaluating which particular juice is worth the squeeze.

author: NoahNeedleman

Was hanging last night with some friends, a couple big producers in the country world were there, (more platinum records on their walls than Beckley type guys.)

One, just bought a vintage c12. I asked how he was enjoying it and he said “man it just solves problems so I don’t have to- I love it cause I get to focus on what matters.”

The second is remodeling his house where his studio is, so he’s working out of a small writers room at universal with an Apollo Solo, an SM7, and a  telecaster. I asked him how his work was sounding and he said “It’s a great reminder that thinking about how things are “supposed” to sound doesn’t always make it sound better in the end. I’m so constrained I can really only focus on the things that matter.”

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I'm totally with you on all this.

The question for me is less about the credit/ title, and more about the role. How do you get perspective at the end of the record making process? This role is changing, and we'd all be smart to understand where it's headed.

I get hired to finish songs a lot. Usually that means I have a "co-producer" credit. Sometimes it means "mixer" credit. Occasionally it's included "mastering." But really what I'm hired for is that combination of experience and technical knowledge. I'm an outside ear who knows how to fix what's missing. This role of "finisher" is really where a lot of the producer/ mixer/ mastering engineer profession is headed. The distinction between those roles is getting blurrier. 

Mixing engineers have moved from pulling up faders on the console and creating a mix (old school "mixers") to often just pulling up the rough mix of stems and making finishing touches (Jon, Manny, Serban, Tony, Bainz, etc.).

In this way, the "mixing engineer" profession is moving away from manipulating raw sounds to manipulating nearly finished mixes. This is sounding more and more like what a "mastering engineer" does. Now there's "stem mixing" and "stem mastering" too, further blurring the lines. These are all just slightly different configurations of the same thing. Who do you hire to get perspective and then act on it?

Those of us that are finishers or mixers or mastering engineers or whatever would be smart to think about how to adapt to the direction this is all headed. 

I want us all to win. I think we need to step back and expand how we think about the roles. It's the best way for us all to have careers.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
It sucks when someone comes down on you for anything tho. Like I am absolutely the hardest on myself, so anyone else tryna be hard on me feels immediately like piling on. Tough to hold your cool through that. 

When I worked at the Cheesecake Factory in my early 20s, the regional manager was a woman larger than the man who was the local gm, and whenever she came to town he’d get real meddlesome and annoying to his staff, making us all worried that somehow our normal workflow wasn’t good enough. It was bad vibes. 

But I’ll never forget a coworker coming over to me and saying, “can you imagine the two of them having sex?” And then walking away like servers do after dropping a one-liner at a table. 

I laughed, but honestly it changed my entire perspective on managers or bosses or anyone in authority. They’re just people, dealing with their own anxieties either heroically or poorly, and I can choose how much of that take on myself. And if I do choose to, I do it out of compassion, not fear. 

… I hope that makes sense.

author: cian riordan
content: First time I pulled an all nighter with EV was when he was mixing a Slash live album (Made in Stoke). We had to mix in 5.1 so we had NS10s setup around the console on old tape boxes and had everything up on the console. It was just under 2 hrs of music and we each took an end of the console and were just going at it with Flying Faders... I think thats where I really learned about the power of automation. How much more effective it is just to turn something up or down for a second as opposed to trying to compress/EQ/or saturate your way out of a problem.

author: Slow Hand
content:
For the last few years I've chosen a theme for myself that informs my actions for the coming year. Something that I want to refine and develop in myself. This isn't an outright goal with a conclusion, but more of a practice to build and lean into. A guiding light that will inform the choices I make. An opportunity to follow whenever it presents itself.

For example, 2023 was the Year of Intuition and Sensuality. Those are separate themes (more like a major and a minor theme). 

Intuition was about vulnerability and instinct. Jumping into things and figuring them out as I go. Diving in and not overthinking. Hacking it out in real time. Trusting myself.

Sensuality was about connecting with my body and my senses. Savoring things. Observing them. Feeling things deeply and being present in my body.

For each theme I usually come up with a big list of situations, activities, opportunities, and practices that I intend to pursue whenever the present themselves. And then I do them! 

They're also things to contemplate: What does this mean to me? What does it mean to others? How does it influence my life?

author: Rob Domos
content:
The idea that the story we tell ourselves about the work is a distraction from the actual work applies as much outside of the studio as it does in. “What will XYZ person think about me because of the decision I make” is a pretty useless thought in terms of actually making the right decision. 

Adjacent thought; thinking about the preamp instead of about the song/performance is like thinking about your haircut while on a date. It’s so far outside of the bounds of what the moment is actually about that it’s comical. The above are all just pernicious ways of escaping the vulnerability required to show up in reality, when showing up is the whole task

author: cian riordan
content:
In the studio, this was like getting a golden ticket. It turns out, there’s no shortcut to greatness. You have to put in the work. Want to get a great drum sound? Do the work. Pick out the right drums. Spend time tuning them. Put them in the right place in the room. Try different places in the room. Try different drums. Setup some microphones. Listen. Adjust. Move the microphones. Maybe change the drums. Maybe change the microphones. Maybe they don't sound good because the part isn’t right? Maybe it's something else in the arrangement? Take it out. Try it. 

This takes quite a bit of motivation to get this deep in the weeds. But the results? Well, they were always unquestionably great. Could it have been fine with less work? Maybe. But you’d never know. And nobody is going to care about this record more than you are.

author: cian riordan
content: I also want to add that I recently built a new mix room and decided against using tube traps per the advice of the Unf•ck guys. They took a much more targeted approach to soaking up low end by building limp mass absorbers. Instead of the more broadband approach of the tube traps, these required measuring the room pre-treatment and figuring out what the problem areas were. Then, these absorbers are manufactured to specific problem frequencies in the room. I was a little skeptical at first but man, the low end in here is just absolutely magic. I've never been in a room where I can walk around and the low end stays so even throughout. The downside to these absorbers is that they are tailor made to fix the flaws in my specific room, so if I ever move, they'd likely be useless somewhere else. That's the real benefit of tube traps is the ability to move them around from studio to studio, and even to different places within the studio to address various problems.

I have a deep passion and commitment to music and my day job allows me to pursue it the way I’ve always envisioned it. I am not in a position life-wise to financially struggle through finding my footing in the industry as a full-time pursuit, but I take it as seriously as if I had to. The practice of mastering, the way I envision it, is fucking expensive and my day job allows me to do it the way I see it. I struggle with imposter syndrome being an “outsider” but that’s never not been a thing for me as a creative. Just comes with the territory.

author: BatMeckley
content:
This is a pretty good encapsulation of what I’ve tried to Mr Miyagi here in this discord since I’ve joined. Virtually all the people I know that have made it work in this business have THIS in common. They might not all be compression wizards, they might not all play an instrument… there’s so many things different about them… but THAT duality seems to be the common thread of everyone I know who makes it (which again, is why I posted that  Noel interview). I can argue passionately about the difference between mics or even converters, the specifics of Bluetooth latency, and also truly believe in “just get to work”. I can relentlessly take the piss out of Cian and deeply respect him as a person and his talent at the same time.

I’ll admit I sometimes get bummed when it seems that a couple people read it as “oh, the trick is to be rude about someone’s Nan”, and it’s like no, the trick is to take music seriously and treat it as the magic gift that it is, while not taking ourselves too seriously and sucking all of the magic out of it.

Noel seems to encapsulate that better than I am currently.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Fun question! I hate to complicate an already nuanced premise at the outset, but when I observe my own choices and think of each category I see myself living both sides of all three spectrums, but in different domains:

**For example:** I could be short-term in career objectives and overt achievement and long-term oriented in relationships and satisfaction. Cutting edge in creative pursuits, but classics in my personal taste. Specialist in my mode of expression, and generalist in my interests.

The more I subdivide and examine the question the more I find exceptions to everything. I am steeped in knowledge, but I seek wisdom above most things, which some philosophies would consider contradictory.

This Anais Nin quote comes to mind:

> "We do not grow absolutely, chronologically. We grow sometimes in one dimension, and not in another, unevenly. We grow partially. We are relative. We are mature in one realm, childish in another. The past, present, and future mingle and pull us backward, forward, or fix us in the present. We are made of layers, cells, constellations."

I think people are extremely lopsided and unbalanced when you start to drill down into their psyches, and that's wonderful! 

For the sake of refining this question and narrowing the scope, should we confine these three axis to only record making? Or do we want to approach it in a holistic sense?

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s tricky, it’s a bit how I was saying the old head front of house guy was probably underselling his knowledge. 

There is a friend of mine that’s
worked on some massive records, and they did a bunch of interviews and tik toks about all of the work and automation and plugins and processing that it took to make the record sound great, and while they work a ton, it always struck me that if I was the artist I would be hesitant to work with such a “look how responsible _I_ am for the end product” producer. 

I’ve always tried to come from the perspective of whenever I’m asked about a record I’ve worked on with “man, the artist just sounds like that in the room, I was just lucky to be there and try and capture the magic” 

It’s not an apples to apples comparison with Rubin, but benefit of the doubt style MAYBE there’s a bit of that in there? I’ve always thought the kids just want to believe the person on the poster is the genius. They don’t need to know an 40 yo married couple wrote Sk8r Boi.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Couple ways I see this:
1) art is never completed, merely abandoned.

2) no one is actually a perfectionist, as evidence by nothing they have done is perfect. Guaranteed.

3) I think it is far more comforting to judge our work by the potential, vs the actual. When you actually release a piece of work it is now out there to be consumed, enjoyed, criticized, evaluated. It’s so much easier to just have this amorphous concept of an in progress piece of work, because it can be as grand and as loved as you can imagine in your head.

author: peterlabberton
content: Just offering this as another perspective, but one that's more focused on engineering, not producing: I worked on *so* many lame ass records and projects that I'd never show anyone, but I saw every one as an opportunity to build my engineering chops on someone else's dime. This was mainly as a staff engineer at a big studio, which is its own hustle, but if you can look for something to learn/improve/gain on each project, I don't think every single session needs to be the most artistically/personally satisfying thing. author: Ross Fortune
content:
For real. Yesterday had an almost hallucinogenic texture to it - like, I’d spent time with all of the elements of this production, and I felt like I’d seen them from all angles. In a way I had - from all of the exterior angles that were visible to me.

But when my pal jumped on and started working with the drum mics (a lot of Decap and Saturn in split band - drawing all sorts of wild life, depth and dimension out of an innocuous extra snare mic).

It was as if he’d stuck his fingers through the shell of a watermelon and pulled it wide open, red stuff and pips flying everywhere. All I’d thought to do was rotate the melon on different axes and shine lights on it to get different shades of green. It never occurred to me to pull the insides out and splatter everything red.

author: Andy Lawson
content: just taking a break from a mix.. i missed a lot.. the only thing i know is the harder i have worked, the better the industry has been to me.. i started with nothing,  zero $$$$ in my bank account (i did have a photocopied version of the pro tools manual),zero skills, zero training (apart from listening to every song i could)living in a tiny share house room with no windows. but i've slogged and slogged. i've always wanted to be the best at what i do and i carry that with me daily. am i the best, absolutely not. but everyday i go into battle and try to believe i am or want to kick someone else's ass.. it's got me to the point where i bought a house and support my family. i think without that mindset i would have given up on this job years ago. The industry does not play fair and never will, but i firmly believe you can play fair. i've never tried to steal a job from a friend, sneak my way into something. i've just tried to be open and honest with my clients and peers. that's my word vommit on reading above.. lol.... Workhard, Think big, Enjoy! that's all we've got

author: Brian Reynolds
content: So I climbed into my 2010 Volvo S80 today. And for the first time in 2025. I was going to listen to my music on the speakers. I plugged in my usb c adapter. Into the coaxial cable that runs into the center console, for that true old analog gold plated warmth. Turned the windows and volume all the way up, then as I prepared to hit play. I was blanketed with the all to familar tension. That very same feeling from when I was going to have to sit next to one of the two dudes on the middle school basketball team. Who took as their daily task, to pay homage to ancestral animal social structures, by drowning any nearby male counter part with sack taps, donkey punches, and nail whip flicks. You just preemptively flinch at the inevitable pain from their onslaught. I hit play on a mix that is -5.8 lufs at peak. No proverbial donkey punch to my thighs this time. The song didn't overload the speakers at any point. As I heard the mix in my studio. I heard it here. The things I loved about it. I loved it here. The things I was unsure about. I was equally unsure about them here. My eyes welled up a bit with fulfillment and gratitude. It took me longer and cost more than I could of ever imagined, when I started this journey. But I got here. No longer do I have to worry about translation of the mix. I can focus all my worry on the feeling and vibe of the performace. I'm willing to let my ego have this one, this mix punches with any modern mix on earth. On any system. (Sounds killer on the Meta Ray Bans. And those speakers are rutheless honest. Ive heard alot of overloaded low end mixes on em) And back to the gratitude. I wanted to thank this place. I couldn't have done it without yall. I'd still be in a pitch black room looking for a switch that felt like it was hidden on the ceiling. Now back to work! Have a great day yall!!

author: cian riordan
content: On this note, I'll say that I LOVE these drives. My workflow in the past has basically been to buy a new 1GB SSD drive every few projects. When I had my setup on a laptop, this allowed me to always have access to projects I was working on the go (printing stems on the couch while watching TV? Yes please). In addition to using these SSDs, I'd always keep local backups with 'Sync Folders Pro' -- RIP Sync X -- on a cheaper, larger capacity USB drive. Being an anxious data archiver, I also signed up for Backblaze a few years ago as a cloud solution in case my studio burns down. Its a really great service, but the caveat they have with your drives is you *can* back up externals, they just need to be connected to your computer every 30 days. So I bought this monster USB3 hub and just had all of these fucking SSDs connected to my computer whenever it was setup at my studio. It worked fine for a few years, but I ran out of space again a few weeks ago and decided to futureproof mysetup a little bit. I ended up getting a thunderbolt Drobo. That way, I could have redundant storage for archived projects (which also gets uploaded to backblaze) but without having 16 drives on my desktop. Now I just have two of those samsung SSDs -- one work, and one as a backup. They run lightning fast and I get to keep having local backups in case I fuck the dog moving files around after a few glasses of wine. Then, when I run out of space, I just offload onto the Drobo and it's locally redundant, and also backed up on the cloud. Thank you for coming to my TED talk.

author: Deleted User
content:
I don’t think there is a single person that was smartest or wisest. People all have different areas they are smart in, or wise in. The most intuitive, most empathetic, most knowledgeable (in ____), etc

I don’t really know what smart means, but people that appear smart are very nuanced about the things they don’t know or understand. They can articulate what they know, they can put things together with intuition, they can develop ideas and concepts without being fed one.

My observations of people with great wisdom seem to be the people who spend great deal of time processing emotions and self reflection. And they share what they learn from the place of empathy. 

I had a guitar teacher, he never gave me “real answers” to my questions. He always told me at the end of his version of guidance and helpful tools or some joke (again not an answer)“you’ll find the answers to any questions inside you”. Which was a wtf moment to me because I wanted the answer right then and there- but I realized often times a lot of things that are not factual cannot be answered by anyone but me because even if anyone gave their own version of answer it would not be relevant to me or I wouldn’t understand any of it unless I can make sense of things myself. That was one of the greatest and live changing advice I have received in life.

author: jantrit
content:
I’m going  fail to properly put this into words but the ability to extrapolate and have an understanding of the learning process/ be driven to take that journey. One example would be this, someone comes in fresh expecting you to spoon feed them the knowledge, that’s not super helpful. But someone comes in and can say, “oh that’s a Patchbay, can you show me how it works”. You can teach those people anything. The desire and hunger to learn on their own and the ability to acquire knowledge for themselves has been a huge divide I’ve noticed in the intern/ college community.  

One time we were setting up a session and I was explaining to our intern my thoughts about which headphones we’d give to each station. (This pair has better bass, we’ll give them to the bass player. These are open back we’ll give them to the horn section so they can blend better) The very next session without having to mention it, she had placed the same headphones in the same places AND ALSO she then took that info and made a the judgement that we’d give the nicest most comfy pair to the vocalist. That’s what I mean about extrapolation.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
I moved here 2 years ago with a bunch of savings and making very little money in music. It took me about a year to pull in enough income from mixing and spotify streams where I could stop living off savings and only on music income. 

But, It IS so expensive to live here, and I like to do things. typical night out is like $80 after drinks and ubers. Gas is $80. An egg sandwich is $16 lol. The constant worrying of if i was going to make enough that month got to me, so of a couple months ago, I returned to a freelance software engineering gig 3 days a week. Never been happier. A _lot_ of people in LA are doing the same: _side hustles are your friend_ . 

Another thing i'd add is when you first move here, try to combine your studio and living expenses. Studio spots here start at like $1800 a month and go up from there. I live in a beautiful house in silverlake with roommates where I have a room, my own bathroom, _and my own studio_ in the furnished garage for $1300. Try to get something like that.

author: Rollmottle
content: haha...I'm a UX designer by trade and would have approached this problem differently. i don't know that we actually have a problem where we need a more structured and rigid way of soliciting feedback on music. maybe in certain high volume scenarios, i can see the use case. for mixing and mastering, putting an interface in front of somebody that makes a user think "oh shit, i can comment down to the every last second!" seems ripe for 1. woodshedding and focusing on things that in any other listening context wouldn't matter 2. makes me think I *have* to say something. as my client, i'd much rather you take the music wherever you feel most comfortable in whatever way you want to consume and just listen and then communicate back to me however you'd like without the pressure of a UI that might be unnatural to that workflow in front of you. it's a philosophical thing i suppose...i never want to add friction to your natural way of thinking about something, especially your own music.

author: Slow Hand
content:
People who don't win Grammys will never be losers unless their goal was to compete and win a Grammy. Then they're losers by their own competitive standard, and losing is all part of the game.

Everyone else can only stand to gain by being nominated. The act of being nominated is a reward in it's own right. It's a net positive and validating moment for anybody's career. While it may be disappointing not to win, hopefully they'll never feel that they're losers for failing to win something that they didn't ask for.

This is all to say that it's a matter of mindset. If you're not actively trying to win a Grammy, then a loss shouldn't be construed as some demeaning thing and the nomination is still a net positive. I don't think it's on the Grammys to regulate people's emotional state.

author: gatewoodsensei
content:
Schedule, schedule, schedule. I use a productivity app called Notion. Make multiple bottles ahead of time. That way you don’t have to stop working to make a bottle. You can pull them out of the refrigerator whenever you need, warm em up and you’re good to go. Most formula last at least 24 hours in the refrigerator. Breast milk is easier to work with because you can freeze it, grab it, and thaw it when you’re ready to use it. Plan your breaks around feeding. When he’s playing or napping, you can work. Make sure he’s visible tho. Have a bassinet, bouncer, or something next to your chair. Open backs help when mixing because you can hear if he cries. Babies love white noise. Play that shit on loop while he sleeps and he’ll be out for hours at a time. Use brown switches for your keyboard if you can get them. Those are extremely quiet and won’t wake the baby. 

That’s off of the top of my head. I might think of something else and add it here. CONGRATULATIONS!!!

author: Slow Hand
content:
I've never considered myself someone who's had substance issues of any kind (thankfully). I'm approaching the end of a self-imposed 3 month break from alcohol and as I near the finish line I don't feel as if I'm in any hurry to return to where I was.

I've been a casual drinker for over 15 years and recently have found that even 1-2 drinks the night before were leaving me feeling like shit in the morning, so I opted to remove them from the equation and see how I felt after my trial period.

No surprise, but it's been a positive one. I'll still drink on occasion, but it feels great not defaulting to that habit. It's probably been the confluence of several factors in my life, but right now I feel as good as I've ever been. I feel present and in-tune with the world around me and I think I'd be far less effective if I hadn't taken this break.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
I often use the proMB freeband mode as a basic “denoiser” for high end. 

If I get a vocal with some schmutzy noise, I will dip the high end, but have the lower vocal fundamentals trigger expansion back to a “flat” frequency whenever the vocal is actually singing. Release time to taste from there.

Can also help with an over resonant drum or lower “hum” issue where you want to dip most of the time, but then have it be “flat” whenever the snare hits, or whatever.

Comes in handy for post work too. Cleaned up a lot of VO’s and SFX recordings with those methods.

author: hyanrarvey
content:
Yo speaking on what @Nomograph Mastering said a few days about staying cool…we have a producer in and so the whole room is a giant mess (like most studios are when they are locked out) and we sold an amp and we wanted to make profiles/name of it before it went out the door 

So the patchbay is a huge mess and I hooked up all the routing and wasn’t getting signal and I started to lose my cool and got super frustrated, Rick calmed me down and we worked out what problem was (I forgot I was feeding the the amp from the di multed on the patchbay instead of feeding it from the converter to run tones..) and after I got cooled down it clicked on why I wasnmt getting signal.



It’s extremely difficult to not get frustrated when trouble shooting and not get overwhelmed by a full patchbay but if you just take a second and breathe/calm down and start reversing your signal flow you’ll find the culprit and move on




Long story short as an engineer you gotta be the calmest one in the room

author: cian riordan
content: Nail on the head. I think I had mentioned this in a previous post, but these days notes tend to come in real time -- via text messages, dropbox comments, or sometimes even thoughtful emails. I'll usually take a quick glance, but then dump everything into a note file so I have everything in one place when I sit to do the revision. This can be useful when you'll get a thread of notes like 1) I'm not sure about the drum sound, it feel so x... then 2) someone else will chime in saying I love the drums! I think x is the problem then 3) first person is hesitant and shrugs of their not, even though it may still bother them. That way I can try and string together some sort of move that will hopefully make everyone happy. If you're dealing with a band -- and you're producing/engineering -- you'll have had the benefit of seeing the dynamic. Sometimes you get some people that are more engaged and tweaky, others that are unsure of EVERYTHING, and then people that when they say something, they're usually right, as infrequent as that may be. This is very useful during mix notes time because you have context. If you're just getting flies flown to you and you've never met the band/artist, thats certainly a bit more of a challenge and will likely require more work on your end to smooth things out.

author: peterlabberton
content: Thinking about numbers, i.e. a 2 db boost vs 4 db, and then endlessly ABing/being conservative with moves to a fault. At my old staff engineer gig I got to assist Joe Chiccarelli on a handful of tracking/mixing sessions. The most eye opening was assisting him mixing the latest Hellogoodbye record. He’d mix 2 songs a day on average, and just breeze through cranking on the 550 eqs in the console—not a care in the world what the numbers said. I’d take recall notes and print stems/various mixes and he and the band would go have lunch/dinner. Seeing him repeatedly just crank on shit until it sounded compelling was huge. Obviously, you need to have developed the instincts to do that tastefully and have it sound great, but that sent me down a path of being fearless and trying to not get hung up on looking at shit.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
Setting an achievable long term exercise goal and making a plan on how you'll get there is a major key for getting into and keeping you exercising. And doing stuff that isn't boring too.
I've always found doing a little often is way more valuable than doing 1 really intense workout here and there. (this is relevant for progression in any kind of physical activity too, and progression matters because its what will keep you interested long term)
Eating well and sleeping enough is also a major key. I know this is really simple stuff but If you make a habit of these things and stay consistent, you'll notice drastic improvements in physical and mental health, and you won't ever feel like exercise is a chore.

If there's one topic that I actually know a lot about, even down to a deep scientific level, it'd be this sorta stuff, so feel free to hmu with any qs whenever lol

author: Rollmottle
content: What worked for me is liberating myself from the idea that every session and every song needed to be gold. You have to be OK with it just not happening some days, but you do have to make yourself put in the work. I have hundreds and hundreds of ideas that went nowhere, or sparked a new idea, or were the basis of some of my favorite work. And you are probably doing yourself a disservice by putting pressure on yourself to thread the needle every single time you go into the studio. That's exhausting. There are no harsher critics than ourselves. But sometimes noodling around aimlessly with no stated purpose or intention is what will get you there. Be OK with working for the sake of working and see what starts to happen.

author: Bonati12461
content: And sorry to bang on about this, but something that is critical to the audio quality on a record that is way out of most pro-audio people’s view is the state of the cutting lathe being used to do the master cut. Many people working in audio have never even seen such a machine. They are complicated - there are techs who work on consoles who won’t touch cutting lathes. IMO the best lathes were made by Neumann in the 70s/early 80s, and that was a long time ago. You have a TON of electronics and mechanics that need to be refurbished / restored to get the lathe to make some great cuts. Some engineers are cutting on some nicely restored systems and some are using some OLD stuff which should have been pulled for maintenance decades ago. Imagine if 50% of the records today were mastered on 50 year old loudspeakers with blown drivers and mismatched crossovers. We might notice.

author: austenballard
content:
I used to find when I worked on anything stoned I would end up over-focusing on one element, or making one thing WAY too loud, and also generally be slow. But weed never really agreed with me anyway, I gave it up years and years ago.

I kind of worry that any substance will negatively affect my hearing; there are some known negatives. Alcohol decreases your HF sensitivity, opioids disrupt level perception (to me, it always feels like everything I'm hearing is going into a slammed limiter) and stimulants like cocaine and amphetamines can (IIRC) reduce your sensitivity to loud sounds, putting you at risk of hearing damage

author: shaunobi
content: Tbh… I have lots of keyboards, mostly mechanical, some rather expensive. I pull the key caps and throw them in denture cleaner overnight. Works wonders. author: BatMeckley
content:
Ehhhh. I found Collier confusing the fact that Rubin is wildly commercially successful with that being Rick’s intention. Like “if he’s wildly commercially successful it must be because he’s trying to be commercially successful, priority one”. Which I dont necessarily think is true. 

There’s often a chip on the shoulder of ultra high level musicians (and sometimes writers) that their talent doesn’t directly correlate to commercial success, and they’re salty at the people that they perceive less talented that do “better” than them (I call it the Jason Falkner syndrome). With writers it’s the guy salty that the only time people really want to hear their songs is when someone else sings them (the Butch Walker syndrome). I’m getting a little of that from Jacob here, which honestly really surprised me because he never struck me as that guy.

So I enjoyed how they sounded but started getting migraines regularly which had never been a problem in my life before. I looked into whether there was any data showing that increased emf exposure near the head was correlated to increase in migraines and it turns out there is data on this and there is a correlation. I took 2 days off from the maxes and the migraines subsided completely. 

Maybe strapping a small computer to one’s brain 9 hours a day is a bit much? I’d still use them for short bursts but will use dumber headphones 99% of the time

author: Dereck Blackburn
content: There was some advice I heard years ago that was along the lines of "Never make a record when you're building a house." and every single time a client has come to me wanting to record or mix right before they're doing major life shit (building a house, moving, going back to school later in life, career change, *divorce*, loss of a parent, etc.) I have always said give yourself 3 months to process on your own and then lets talk. Anytime I haven't done that the project runs long, the client gets burned out, the client goes to someone else I know then I have to listen to them/see them complain about their new headache. Every situation is different but I just got off the phone with a potential client who started off the call with "Sorry I'm late, we just started interviewing contractors for a home renovation and I'm also trying to coordinate players for this record I want to make while we're out of our home for a year."

author: Pio
content:
I really like an old classical theological meaning for the word mystery, and have found it helpful when thinking about things difficult/impossible to understand: a mystery can be understood as something which of its very nature lies beyond, or above, finite intelligence.

I like some effects of this view on understanding - it’s no so much that we can never hope to understand certain things. It’s not so much a defeatist attitude, that there’s no point in even trying. It’s a little more that I may never be able to fully grasp certain things - being a being of (very, lol) finite intelligence - but that doesn’t mean there’s no merit in seeking to grow my understanding of them all the same.

author: spectrummasters
content:
“I may never be able to grasp certain things “ / mystery . Love this man . This is it right here imho . Since primordial times we ve been staring into the great unknown . My friends and I got really into the beat poets , Ken Kesey ,aldous Huxley, Joseph Campbell  etc in our teens , going to school near Glastonbury and Stonehenge . There’s tons of ancient English mystical stuff down there . I take the view that we are the universe investigating itself . Probably just a “microorganism “ of a much bigger conceptual realm that we can catch glimpses of but not rationalise . I think Donald Hoffman has the closest view to mine I’ve heard articulated thus far . 

I like your fruit bowl analogy because it minds me of Picasso and Dali and how they’d render the bowl . 
When I was a lifeguard we had sessions for autistic children with high support needs , and the children would be reacting to stimuli that I could not “see “ . They’d be speaking to people or getting a scare from something I couldn’t see . I never once thought that they’re seeing things that aren’t there …..imho they are seeing things through a different filter to me .

author: Rollmottle
content:
Some people will never realize their agency. That doesn’t mean they don’t have it. We all have it. The degree to which we build upon and leverage what we do have is our puzzle to solve.

I’ve had countless conversations with lost folks who think success and the things they say they want just happen. It is VERY difficult to teach self determination to people who don’t inherently believe that taking direct action toward a goal makes things start to happen. A lot of people don't believe it can be that simple. This doesn't mean it's easy. It can be hard to overcome one’s wiring and circumstances. And sometimes people need to learn the hard way. But, outside of the extreme, everybody’s got the agency to make their desired outcomes happen. Some need to work at it harder than others. For some, it comes easier. And sadly some never realize that their outcomes are in their hands. But what a powerful realization it should be that the things we think we can’t do are often just ourselves telling us we can’t do them, when in fact we absolutely can.

author: cian riordan
content: That's super fair given the circumstances of... *gestures to everything around us*. I'm lucky to be a full-time working mixer/engineer. I'm not in the stratosphere in terms of accreditation, but I'm comfortably making a healthy living, am married, have a child, and own a house. If I relied on big breaks, I'd be absolutely nowhere. 99% of my success has come from rubbing shoulders with the right people and finding opportunity that way. A night out drinking with friends leads to meeting other people who you stay in touch with. Pretty soon they'll need help with something and then off you go, that leads to the next. 75% of what I work on is smaller potatoes... most of it will never get heard, but it pays most of my salary. And the 25% of work I have that makes it through the filters has all come through connections I've made through smaller gigs. Networking is really key. And if you're a social person, it's even better as it'll help offset the time spent alone in a soundproof room, pulling your hair out over a stupid kick drum sound.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I went to help a fellow engineer buddy record some drums today at his studio, and it made me think of something Jon Castelli said on the Conversations or LWMR podcast - he challenged the idea of being out of your comfort zone to grow, and look at the Benefits of the comfort zone.

My buddy is a great engineer and great drummer in a great and, so all great things. But his setup was just incredibly different than mine; he uses Studio One, I use pro tools (he’s also used to Pro tools and recently bailed on it). He’s using a combo of Antelope Discrete 8 and an Audient ASP880 and some good outboard pres (Vintech and Summit audio). His monitoring killed me, some small dynaudios which sounded okay and some ProAc’s. He had some decent mics. I brought my 8 Channels of UTA and a bunch of mics and was there just to put our heads together, and I was going mostly press record so he could drum for his bands record.

Anyway, we spent about 4+ hours trouble shooting Studio One, his computer, and the interfaces -eventually finding out one of his AD/DA channels was so messed up it sounded like a ribbon mic when it was a condenser. A lot of his mic stands and cables were really junky - he didn’t have enough of the basics on his own.

So many things were just not working as I would expect - my UTA preamps were set at much lower gains than I do at my studio because of his gear. I’m basically ear-blind because of the monitoring, even with headphones, and I’m working in Studio One so I can barely focus on the sound. And he used a normal Apple mouse, I use a trackball. 

Im trying not to complain, but it just blew my mind how much of an uphill battle recording can be just because of simple things being so taxing. We spent about an hour of the 6 hours I was there tracking one song. The rest was setup. It made me realize why we put so much work into making our process simple and getting gear that is effective and reliable.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I actually *just* posted this in a #🎛gear-talk convo, but I'll elaborate in more detail:

I set annual themes for myself.  This year is the *Year of Intuition and Sensuality*.

The *intuition* aspect means that whenever an opportunity arises to do something I will challenge myself to dive right in and intuitively feel my way through it, rather than taking an overhead approach and charting everything out before I act. Don't second-guess. Just go for it.

I'm exceedingly good at planning and analysis, but I'm less comfortable with simply diving headfirst into something, getting messy, and figuring it out as I go. So this year is about me identifying opportunities to do so and hack away without premeditation (I've already got that in spades). Throw myself in and then dig myself out. It's a muscle I want to flex so that I can be more ambidextrous in my approach to situations.

The *sensuality* half is about being more in touch with my body. It's less about health or fitness and more about observing my body and following the sensations. Being more sensual. Whether it's exploring feelings of touch, scent, or flavor. Being attuned to how my body feels when I sing. Or how an instrument through an amp resonates in my body. Following those instincts. Dancing more. Anything that might fall under that umbrella.

author: Deleted User
content:
It was a life changing experience, I used to break dance when I was 8 but I’ve never danced after that and eventually developed walls with dancing. But this experience got me in touch with how connected music and dance are. I always had trouble with percussion parts to fill the groove when I’m arranging- I no longer have that problem.

but not really being a dancer myself- I still feel short of making people move with groove. 

Having communal experience like that weekly was so great for my mental health, and being in servitude playing same rhythm for 30 mins each for people to dance on was a great meditative practice and ego-dropping experience. Also allowed me to discover how much great things can happen within repetition of 1 bar rhythm.

author: LAPhill
content: Sure, but whenever someone says they want the Bonham drum sound, for example, they don't mean it. It sounded big for the time, huge in the arrangement, but if you literally dropped that into a modern mix, it would sound wimpy. We accept the sonics as a part of the totality of a record, in the era it was produced in. Give me the Bonham drum sound experience that's in my brain.

author: Rollmottle
content: i can recommend the tool Figma if you really want to get into designing and visualizing how you want your site to be. it's free and simple and specifically built for designing digital interfaces. you can chuck all your screenshots and ideas on the canvas alongside your wireframes and actual design. you can even prototype it if you want. the learning curve is not high. i use it professionally daily for what it was made for, but i also use it for tons of other things like visualizing signal flow or gear layouts in the studio, mood-boarding, designing non-digital things like rooms and furniture layout, making memes 😂 , etc.

content:
Totally. I've been going through a period these last few months where my enthusiasm to write and produce music has been flagging. I'm still listening to records every day - same as ever - but my approach has been to set the creation part aside completely and focus on the physical pleasures of playing.

For me that means focusing on singing for the first time in my life. Really taking the time to feel the physicality of it and how my body responds. Honing in on the sound and loosening up. I'm also playing more bass and focusing on the sensations and the tone and the articulation in a way that I've neglected for a while. Now I'm enjoying playing and singing together and practicing that with no expectations. I say this as someone who has never considered themselves to be a singer/songwriter. I'm really enjoying it.

The whole project is tied in with my mindfulness practice, and I'm loving the feeling of being unburdened by the need to write and deliver.

author: LAPhill
content:
I know I'm an outlier here as a composer, but I very much feel the spirit of the question and would like to offer a few thoughts. My job is about realizing someone else's vision and pushing that to be the best it can be. If you're being hired as a producer, then like me, you have to believe that you're being hired for your taste and perspective. So the question is, why doesn't it feel good to you? Is there something undiscovered that could make it better?

I've written a lot of music that's outside of my aesthetic or personal tastes. But if I'm on the project, I'm going to be 100% invested in helping make that thing what it needs to be. There's a way into music that's outside of your vibe - sometimes it's getting excited about new techniques, sometimes it's exploring a genre you're unfamiliar with, and sometimes it's just because the people you're making music with are a good hang. Sometimes, the role of a composer (or producer) is to take their vision and find the version of it that **does **get you excited. We've probably all had that experience of "I really never listen to X, but this one song/artist is just undeniable." So strive for that.

author: peterlabberton
content: Also—and this is probably at the core when I am adamant about, for instance, not getting hung up on converters—one of the most difficult things I think is figuring out *where* to focus your attention, what to care about. You can’t possibly care about every single detail on even a simple, otherwise straightforward song. Learning to focus in on the important bits and actually not care about the irrelevant stuff is, I think, one of the main things you gain with experience.

author: Zach Hughes
content: GC Pro is very informal here in Nashville at least. I walked into their office and said my buddy Andrew told me about them. This was many years ago maybe 2016. The main guy Greg said something like 'oh yeah ANDREW??? heard that one before'. We laughed at my discomfort. He then proceeded to sell me whatever it was I was buying for close to 30% off and that's how it's been since. I've gotten GC Pro quotes that left my VK sales guys flabbergasted from how much of a discount they were giving. My Sweetwater guy never gives me discounts unless I ask sometimes. I picked up that some manufacturers items are 'price locked' and with others the sales folks have more wiggle room. I've found it beneficial asking 'is this product price locked with the manufacturer?'. A little less uncomfy then asking 'can you give me a discount?'.

author: peterlabberton
content: Took this 100% from @cian riordan, but: separate output path for references! I send the mix out 1-2, references out 3-4, and any old mix passes/rough mixes out 5-6. They are all level matched and I can switch between them on my monitor controller. The level matching and real time switching right in front of me is key, to me. I resisted this for ages out of some misplaced sense of pride, but, dude, if you don’t have a good system for references... do it! I also have the outputs of my computer audio routed to record into the ref track via a pair of virtual channels in UAD Console, so I can pull something up on Tidal (!) and record it in directly.

author: Adam Thein
content:
My main tip for using Live live is try and replace as many third party plugins as you possibly can with stock, freeze as much as you can, and most of the latency you experience is going to be coming from internal delay compensation vs I/O latency.  If you are able to optimize your sets as much as possible, you can probably get away with running everything without offloading DSP to a UAD system.  If you are already in that ecosystem by all means!

I built a live set similar to what you have going based off of Daniel Mintseris Lynda (now LinkedIn Learning) videos that were amazingly helpful.  Also in my case I made samplers whenever possible of 3rd party synths if the patch didn't have a ton of modulation internally.  But yeah bottom line is keep an eye on your total device latency on groups (hovering over a group will display the total delay compensation/latency calculation in the Status Bar).

If you have any other questions for me feel free to DM!

Edit: we used a rackmount X32 for in ears that also served double duty as the audio interface running 16 i/o at 48khz and were able to do it on a 2015 macbook with minimal latency

author: ALXCPH
content:
Yes. The same way you do anything in life you want to get good at. Spend a shit load of time doing that thing. There really are no hacks or work arounds if you want to actually get good. An easy free way to do it is just learn as many songs as you can. If you want to really be proficient in the musical language I would recommend learning stuff by ear. It takes a lot longer than looking up tutorials or sheet music. But I promise you will develop your ears infinitely more. Specially in the beginning. Music is a language. Every human being learns to speak and converse before they learn how to spell and know the rules of grammar. Learning theory will only let you put names to sounds so that you can convey musical ideas to their people. Contrary to what a lot of people think, there are no rules, but there are a lot of conventions and traditions, but they keep changing and have lots of exceptions. Learning a shit ton of songs on whatever instrument you choose, will teach you what those conventions are and how to use them. 

In the beginning it’s good to just learn every song you like as well as you can, because it will help keep you motivated as you like the music. Then after a while you will probably want to branch out and try stuff you’ve never listened to or enjoyed before just to challenge yourself. 

The most musical people I know, are the people who wouldn’t know what to do with a Caugmented#9 but can listen to a song once and play it nearly perfectly, because their ears and musical language is so developed from playing a fuck lot of music and not spending time reading about it or watching endless tutorials.

author: austenballard
content:
a number of years ago I consulted on a music tech curriculum for grades 10-12, these were some of the key points:

- Teach the fundamentals, always in a practical way. E.g. "Today we're going to record ourselves speaking" - briefly introduce how a microphone works, what a preamp is, and then get them recording each other. Same with EQ, Compressor, Reverb, Delay, etc.

- Use as many examples from current pop music as possible. Does someone in the class sing or rap? Have the students go through assembling a vocal chain with a compressor, EQ, etc. and record part of a song.

- Don't get too far in the weeds where it's not necessary. High schoolers DO need to know why we have different sample rates and bit depths. They DON'T need to know about aliasing, oversampling, clocking, or dither algorithms.

- Bring history in for context, but don't dwell on it. It's cool to know that we used to need a speaker in an echoey room or a giant metal plate to make a reverb, but focus on how and why they're using effects rather than where they came from
