author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Some people need to be given permission to be themselves, some need to be reminded to listen to others. I think the majority of musicians need the latter, (hi it’s me,) but there’s also a lot of young artists trying so hard to be other people that they forget to explore *themselves.*

When I was 13 and learning how to play guitar, my big brother had a stoner friend who was a Hendrix acolyte. I begged him to teach me Hey Joe, and so he played me the opening riff, full speed, and then stared at me with a deadpan bloodshot eyed stoner look. 
I asked to do it again and then again then to break it down in to smaller increments until he stopped, looked at me and said “you will never be as good at guitar as me.” 

That was a defining moment for me. Not because it made me shrink or want to be better than him, but because I realized a) I never thought I would be better than him and I didn’t care, and b) I let the learning, rather than the result, become my obsession. 

Some of us need encouragement to keep going, others need to be told what we’re doing wrong.

author: Zack Hames
content:
This is the double edged sword of audio interfaces being so cheap and available and marketed. *someone* will do the work for cheaper. (race to the bottom) 

I love artistic autonomy - every musician should be able to record themselves and understand that process and any budding engineers should be able to get into it without spending a fortune.

These are great and big questions. When Jon C. talks about his mix rates it makes a lot more sense (including a studio fee, etc) and is comparable to other industries in the world. But until a label is paying you and independent artists are your clients, there’s just not a chance you can charge like that and get work. But I think that’s why there’s so much talk about raising your rates and valuing yourself and also providing value and having higher stakes projects. 

Anyway, rambling. I know other smarter people will chime in.

What’s interesting to me is that these dichotomies never actually go away. Edward mentioned it being biological. There’s something real human about it. 

I studied theology for a long time, and Christianity is riddled with diametrically opposed readings of the same text. Rather than synthesizing ideas, Christians start whole wars. 

The conversation of ATC vs PMC, Preset vs Bespoke, gets very tiresome, but I don’t think we ever get away from it. At any level.

author: peterlabberton
content: Totally into this. Sometime in high school I wanted to be an architect. A good family friend is a great architect—and a charming grouch. He took me out to a build site one time and just scared me away from doing it—“if you design a building and even 30% of it comes out how you want after the developers and the city have their way you’ll be very lucky… this job is a total hassle and pain in the ass dealing with x y and z other thing…” etc. I really think he was doing exactly this: if it scares him away, it’s not for him. It did scare me away, but my family saying how music wasn’t going to be viable and I need to focus on something else didn’t. 🤷🏻‍♂️ I think it’s a good test of where your real focus and drive lies.

author: Deleted User
content:
Spotify was not even supposed to be a paid service… their model and vision was never having to pay for music again; and letting THAT be high quality experience as if you are playing records you bought. They did indeed do that, and I don’t think it will go back. 

It was decentralization they were after. the record industry was already beyond rescue (to go back to its heyday) so they wanted a better piratesbay where people can hear the music right away, and not the messed up mp3 that has been converted to different codecs multiple times. The platforms opening up to everybody is why someone like myself or my clients can upload any kind of music. 

I mention all of this to say… I think that’s what they wanted. But I think they were hoping more people would use the free version so they can juice more profit out of the ads. I don’t think they were expecting this many people to go premium, which lowers the value of each ads… (because they won’t be listened to as much)

author: EliHeathMusic
content: I have a M.M. (jazz performance) and when I was living in New York and teaching part time, the degree may have helped me land the jobs I had but never got me an increase in pay. This is going off of a fairly small sample size though (a charter public high school and a private music school) and I stopped teaching in schools after about a year. I definitely got a lot of other things out of my Master's program (skills, network, artistic development, my Protools perpetual license, etc) and the degree would qualify me for certain academic jobs if I were to ever go that direction in the future. My main recommendation for grad school would be to do it for more reasons than just the certification and potential pay increase, and ideally find a program where the costs are mostly or entirely covered.

author: Juliette
content:
— Approach your goals with realism, always full send it and don’t be afraid to fail. 

— We’re inherently always trying to be as intimate with our craft as possible (mainly music, but also movies, chess, tech, etc.) Separate yourself from it sometimes for the sake of your love for it. Do something you hate or you’re afraid of just once and it’ll reinvigorate your existing love or gift you a feeling you’ve never had before for something new. 

— Talk to people you’ve never talked to before. Expand your community and let them be apart of your bubble. If they’re weird, you’ve got just as much right to remove them from your bubble.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I love the short burst aspect of this a lot, I never would have thought of that. For lyrics, I have mostly done “journal entry” per day to amass tons of material to pick through later. I realized years later that almost all my completed songs with lyrics came from those bits of writing so I think I need to go back to that! (I don’t write lyrics a lot anymore).

For the music aspect, I relied heavily on just pure instinct / jam it out for so many years, but working on commercial music made me start to set a lot more intention in my writing which helped immensely in all aspects. I guess my favorite thing is mostly to try to write a fully structured song in a day (4-5 times a week). The limitation of a day gives me enough flexibility to actually create and record an entire track while also not getting TOO hung up on writing a verse, chorus, bridge, etc. there’s no time to overthink!

author: Zack Hames
content:
The idea of “everything is subjective” is garbage because we live objectively. Very rarely are people simply unaffected or don’t respond to experiences. Not experiencing is still an experience.

The way you can give feedback to anything is to think about their goal or the goal of the piece. If they don’t HAVE one, then they don’t need feedback. I doubt anyone collaborating is often denying a response or feedback from another party. 

Not to mention, if a lot of people respond to something positivity or negatively, a consensus is built - usually around culture. Radio Pop music is popular because it’s approachable and simple (or appears to be) based on what our society has built into.

I’ll just stop here, this is an endless discussion. I find it frustrating to talk about because as “deep” as you can go, it feels SO surface level. but I think that’s a ME problem. Talking “Philosophy” never feels good to me personally.

author: peterlabberton
content: Personally, I don't really bother taking these kinds of notes while tracking. If I'm producing something myself, I prefer to just keep moving and try something, then move on as quickly as possible. If it needs to be redone for some reason, I'll just cook up a sound again and not get too hung up on whether it's identical or not—chances are if we're revisiting it, things could be improved anyway. If I'm engineering for someone else, I'll defer to them, but these are usually situations where things are even *more* time-sensitive (i.e. we're renting an expensive studio), and the situation is very unlikely to be recreated anyway. I was very lucky to have subbed in for @cian riordan with St. Vincent for a couple months in the early stages of this new record—nothing was documented (unless I grabbed a quick photo to cover my own ass), it was all just trying stuff, and if it worked it worked, if not, move on and forget it! Mixing is another story—in the (increasingly) rare instance when I'm mixing on a console, I'll figure out some way of recalling for that particular project. This is usually more or less @Rollmottle's method, except I go even more jank-ass and just scribble song names on a post-it and hold it in front of a piece of gear like a mugshot. Anything on the console is either stored in the console automation, or, like the most recent project I mixed on a console, I'll just calibrate all the faders and run stuff through it, but really *mix* in Pro Tools still. 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: ehutton21
content:
If you’re confident enough to hit various scales spanning 2+ octaves in each hand (in sync and delayed/one at a time) and you have a decently strong level of piano sight reading ability, then I’d say a piano teacher might be worth lessons every so often if it’s affordable because I’d say you’re starting to max the limits of your ability to assess your execution of technique (you’ll want someone to actually watch how you move, see where you should go, and give you specific cues on what you can shore up from there). 

But honestly when I was training classical piano regularly as a kid (good god I feel old saying that but I know I’m not lol), majority of upper level technique mishaps stemmed from struggles with proper wrist & elbow position where students would let their form slide (the more advanced the composition you were playing, the harder it became to remember your technique) and so they’d lack the actual strength and muscle twitch to hit harder moves.   That along with finger strength & dexterity would often result in stumbles or slips, which also vary based on how you strike the key. Most common error you’ll see that slows down technique is wrists dipping below the fingers a la traditional keyboard typing at any point in the playing process, and you’re never gonna swing an arpeggio or move fast enough to trill because your physical relation to the keys is what dictates proficiency. The physical aspect is why pianists are brought in so young (I started at supervised playing at 4 and I started instruction when I could get through the alphabet), because you can shape them into technique machines. 

So if you’re looking for max utility, finger drills, wrist position, and scales as much as possible is going to keep you sharp as hell.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
This was lovely to read. I’ve definitely been there on prod projects, and others. I’ll always allow projects to swell to fit the allowed time, which invariably adversely affects the quality of the work.

My vice is a deep seated tendency towards fucking around given the chance, and the energy and time that goes into that fuckery or exploration of alt options (which are NEVER as good as the first thing that inspires me) will ALWAYS have been better spent realising the first idea fully in the initial moment of inspiration.

I know this intellectually, but here I am at 7am voice noting out the structure of a pitch due today - doing the mapping out I should’ve done 4 days ago rather than trying out different drums, micing, guitar tones, etc etc on a 16 bar loop.

If anyone has a solution to this, I’d love to know how you’ve beaten your bad habits into submission.

author: austenballard
content:
> There was a noticeable number of US clients (artists + their entourages, certain producers, and especially writers - usually in pop or hip hop) who treated assistants like “the help” / waiting staff / taxi drivers / some menial worker they felt was beneath them. The first few times it happened, it was kind of shocking, and very off-putting.

I want to add to what Ruairí and Matt B said with another perspective. I've had the privilege of working in some very professional settings, where everyone needs to fade into the background to do their jobs properly, and that's absolutely the case at higher levels. And it makes things work. And everyone's cool about it.

But much of my work has been as producer, assistant producer or project manager/fixer for people working at decidedly lower levels. 

And idk how it is in other countries, but we have a glut of people here in the US who have a certificate from a for-profit recording school that says they know what they're doing, who think they're *the shit* for being in the room with some viral star off YouTube/Instagram/TikTok. But don't know how to use a damn patch bay. 

And when you're on the come up, especially as a writer or producer, you interact with a lot of these people, and you get REALLY sick of them REALLY fast. So that might be the source of some of the condescension you see. It's hard not to get jaded when you have to wade through so much incompetence. I feel like a bitter old man just typing this paragraph tbh but I hope I'm not the only one with this experience.

content:
In other quasi-AI developments, there's some pretty insane tech going on in the latest Unreal Engine demo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dj60HHy-Kqk

About halfway through, they show some tools for moving elements around and the engine intelligently fills in the gaps and hooks it back into the environment seamlessly. Imagine this tech in a DAW - move a chord change, or a section, and all of the bits that would need to be adjusted to make it feel natural just happen automatically. You'd still have the flexibility to go in and adjust as desired, but as a way to instantly try ideas (or, respond to notes), there is a lot of potential there.

author: David Fuller
content:
So sound is captured as electrical signals by disturbing a magnetic field (or in the case of condenser mics, changing the voltage potential across a specially tuned capacitor), which generates an AC voltage corresponding to the compressions and rarefactions in the air. This is a whole topic on its own but tl;dr for dynamics you're moving a magnet back and forth inside a coil of wire, with ribbons you're moving the wire back and forth inside a magnetic field, guitar and bass pickup you're disturbing a magnetic field with vibrating ferromagnetic strings... anyway. 

Linear voltage amplifiers (ie class A, and AB for us audio guys) - which we use for mic preamps, line amps, differential amps, power amps, pretty much anything you can think of - work by using an AC voltage to vary DC current flow. In its most basic form, it works like this: That AC signal from the mic or guitar pickup hits either the grid of a vacuum tube or the gate of a FET, and changes the amount of current that flows from one end to the other (usually cathode to plate in a tube, and usually source to drain in FETs). Stick a resistor between the DC power supply rail and the amplifying element and you get a voltage variance because of ohm's law - current goes down, voltage goes up, and vice versa. So, you end up with a bigger version of the input signal, with its polarity inverted. 

Distortion is a *way* more complex topic and not one I'm equipped to explain, as I don't understand it very well myself.

author: Josh
content:
I’m very late to the convo but this is facts. My brother one day called me during his lunch break at Walmart and he was almost crying because he was so frustrated he couldn’t get enough sales to not work there and he said something along the lines of “I can’t believe people are fine with working here”. And I literally said “Bro, you should be JEALOUS. Imagine how much easier your life would be if you were perfectly content with putting the Mayo in the bag.” 

He hung up on me. 

The next day he goes “Hey man. You’re right. I’m jealous of the people who can Mayo in the bag”. 

And that’s just facts. 

I knew a dude who worked at a really great restaurant as a chef. Not the big chef but one of the chefs. During covid he said “eh I have this crazy passion for cooking but never cook for myself. Why don’t I go sell cars?” And he fucking did it and ended up being the only dude I knew who could make $20k a month selling Toyotas without ever having stimulant dependency in his life. This man was leagues happier after the change mostly because he could finally have Sundays off to watch football.

author: spectrummasters
content: Early pioneers were shut up n dance , Lennie de ice . Quickly following on were shy fx , Dillinja, photek, j Malik, ltj bukem optical etc . All these engineers were set on doing things that have never been done yet with sounds you hadn’t heard yet . This energy is the foundation of all the later U.K. genres . I’d say it met it’s zenith with goldie and rob playforda classic “timeless “ . Which to this day still sounds like the future. The early jungle pioneers moved into U.K. garage as jungle became overground and mutated into drum and bass and went global to meet the world . This is when America picked up on it with dj diesel , then Europe with teebee then Australia with pendulum . The U.K. roots had moved on by then into garage pioneering new Rythms again and during this period younger kids who grew up on jungle began changing garage into early dubstep and grime , again pioneering new sounds like Wiley’s “eski “ sound and croydons dubstep

author: shaunobi
content: There’s an idea in software of “proxy based estimation”. So you collect a history of details about past projects. You have to track your time and clock in and out to have the data. So maybe you know past similar “X’s” took 9 hours on average, or 45 minutes. And you know you work X hours on average a day the last month (I usually take a three month average). And you can then bounce a project quickly up against your estimation process (for me it’s a hundred lines in a spreadsheet and some processing based on team composition but could just be 5 lines in a spreadsheet) in near real-time and get a number of hours. You then take that, apply it to your schedule, readjust your plan if needed (ie to accommodate clients with deadlines or other constraints) and let everyone know the plan. Get fast at it and you’ll always have a smooth backlog of work and never have to work more than X hours a day. That’s the theory anyway 😂

author: BatMeckley
content:
By all accounts she’s one of the best vocal producers/engineers around, so I’ve never had the chance to work with her. Can’t speak for her techniques. 

Revoice something I almost never use. In standalone melodyne on a lot of pop tracks if it’s a centered double I’ll make it spot dead on, almost to the point where it’s phasing, to beef up a lead to cut through a mix. If it’s singer songwriter Elliot smith vibe I’ll hard tune the double and for a tonal center and then let the lead breathe more to keep the character. Left Right doubles  you can’t tune as hard because they’ll start to collapse to mono which defeats the whole purpose.  

So again, it’s usually about working backwards from what you want, what it’s supposed to be, than it is about any one technique

author: spectrummasters
content: I was reading a post by a well known engineer explaining his view on how analogue consoles generate a different sound on a mix that daws can’t . With respect to the power supply , . Id not heard this theory before , I wonder if Anyone else is familiar with it . So he said as a result of a limited power supply available to all the channels  , as the. Different frequency content of the individual channels varies it draws different voltages on the channels , with the lower frequencies (ie bass , kick channels ) demanding a larger share of the available voltage when they “occur “ . This process occurs within the context of a limited available power supply , so it results in a simultaneous dip in power available in some of the other channels  . Hence a natural sort of side chaining in the console. What we saying ? Truth or myth

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: cian riordan
content: A big reason I like the Grace M905 grabbing my computer output digitally as well as the output of my PT converters digitally. That way, things are showing up at 0dBFS from both sources, while also feeding my metering through the same path (Clarity M + spectrum analyzer). With Spotify you need normalization off and volume at full — ideally you’d have Tidal and force control over the DAC and bypass core audio, but I’ve got no gripes with Spotify at this moment.

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
**-) **Offline experiences might be a song or an artist being tied to a memory I cherish - that song played at that party when I kissed a beautiful girl, that song played when I was walking out of the bar piss drunk at 6 am with my best friends, that song I heard when I was at a music festival 10 years ago and the world was a better place etc, that song makes me laugh my ass off everytime I hear it (shoutout Frank Zappa lol)

**-) **It could also simply be a piece that moved me when I first heard it and it made me feel something - take for instance** LCD Soundsystem's** *"All My Friends"*, which is to me still the most poignant anthem about getting older, and it never fails to illicit and emotional reaction in me, even though I've never seen them live or have a specific memory attached to them. 

**-) **What makes me become a fan of an artist is - at least these days -  mostly determined by how consistently the artist's work can get an emotional reaction out of me. Take **Bleachers** for example - I had been aware of them for years, but only with this year's album and after discovering "Hey, their songs are actually ALL that good" I became a fan. 

**-)** There are a only a handful of bands/artists I consider myself a hardcore fan of., where I truly explored their entire catalogue over and over again, and it was almost always because they just continued to impress or move me

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Seriously though....  this was inspired by a pop track string/winds  arrangement.  You'd think "well of course all the sample libraries I bought can do that just as well"  but not imxp....  its that the sample libraries can do "an adequate" job and satisfythe need.  But once you hire world-class players and play it live into mics....  for me it was instantly "we could've bought every sample library and programmed for days but never gotten this quality" in the tiny details.  The bow sounds. The players breathing together. Their adaptation to dynamics. The aleatoric sections where advanced techniques were improvised. Samples can be amazing and do things humans can't...  but the inverse is also true.  There are many context where it's got to be live players, or else your track is just "adequate"

author: Adam Thein
content:
Found this

“I took the head off a snare drum and started whacking it with a wooden ruler, recording it through a Shure 57 microphone,” he says. “As I did that, I started twisting the hell out of the [API 550] EQ around 1 kHz on it, to the point where it was starting to sound more like a crash. I blended that with a snare I found in the Linn itself, which was a 12-bit machine, so it sounded pretty edgy to start with.” But the coup de grace for the sound was when Z pumped the processed and blended sample through an Auratone speaker set upside down atop another snare drum, which rattled the metal snares and gave the result some ambience and even more high end. The whole thing was limited slightly and then sent to a track on a roll of Ampex 456 running on a Studer A800 at 15 ips. Only a slight amount of reverb was added to the track later on.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. It's odd. I had the exact same realization yesterday. Late last night I was writing about the topic to order my thoughts and wrote this:

> While his speech is clearly anti-semitic - absurdly so - it's interesting to note that the things Kanye is being shunned for are never personal trespasses against people.
> 
> The complaints against Kanye are never that Kanye assaulted someone, or sexually assaulted someone, or shouted demeaning things at an individual, or bullied someone, or libeled a person, or cheated someone, or de-frauded someone, or used his considerable resources to ruthlessly handicap someone's endeavor in the way that the hyper-competitive often do.
> 
> Kanye's trespasses almost always reside in the taboo. Saying the things that cannot be said. Never in the realm of personal harm. Always in the realm of upsetting great numbers of people. Never against an individual. I'm not sure what to make of that. Somehow it feels different, if still objectionable and alienating to large numbers of people.

author: spectrummasters
content:
For me , LWMR sets itself apart because it never really struck me as claiming to be introducing some new ground breaking invention / product / idea …..but much more focused on understanding the origins and evolutions of good working practices and why . 

This resonated with me because , I really find myself thinking…..for all these new products like soothe / gullfoss / cla vocals / TGP ….and now stem splitters ….how much better do the records being made today sound / feel than those in the 70s ( for example ) . Like we came out of mono and into stereo and Jesus gains were made .!..for all the new clever software have we made those sorts of gains from it ? I think loudness techniques yes defo , but otherwise ? Hmmm . I feel like the best records today are being made by people who really know their engineering ish…..like LWMR was kinda all about imho . 

So it feels like a lot of the promo on “analogue emulations / stem splitters / multi band resonance tools “ …..although very clever ….kind of miss the point when it comes to becoming good at this mindfuck of mixing

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Timbaland’s talent and contribution to music is something I cherish. Sad when someone of that influence has a take this off base.

I believe the most valuable creative currency of the coming era will be authentic innovation of expression. Creating music that is ahead of the curve of expressing the human experience in a way AI couldn’t have previously copied, since it’s so true to that artist then as a representation of where they are at that time based on all the influences leading up to the moment of creating that art.

There’s always been a flood of copies after something fresh is made, and I believe AI will make it easier for people to follow-up with products like that, but the forefront is too imbued with the energy of the lived energies zeitgeist to be emulated by code - Perhaps one of the few things that code will never be able to do.

I’m open to being wrong, but that’s the thought this gives me.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
I’ve officially competed in many different activities and learned the art of optimizing for first place. I got a thrill in ‘seeing the Matrix’ and coming up with my own ways to do things, but ONLY if it had results tied to it. 

I have a 6th place finish I got over 10 years ago that I’ll never forget, because I was so obsessed with getting top 5 (preferably #1 but I’d always lie to myself that the next threshold would be enough, but it never was) I was destroying my mind and body and my health was affected. I had to stop focusing on competing and find the deeper layers behind what I was really running from by attaching my self worth to competing like a parasite scared of losing its host.

Music was actually such a perfect remedy because I can always improve my ability to translate my ideas into reality, but there is no optimal result. No truly perfect song or finish line. Hunting world records was a life of quick-sand, always trying to keep up with the past while showing you can still do it in the present. 

Those days of competing taught me that entering the ring, doing my best, and letting go of any care of result is where true joy lies. Any connection to an activity and my self worth, or my complicated authentic identity, has nothing to do with the outcome of how my time was spent, but instead the win of having the ratio of the time I spend in life doing what fulfills me.

-

I made music at that time too, but ever since these breakthroughs my music has become far more authentic, which makes me feel like it’s better. It jumped the quality of my work way more than any technique, because now I sit down to express exactly who I am in that moment, and everything else is a subconscious implementation of everything I’ve learned thus far.

author: Dodgy

author: cian riordan
content: In a space that small, as much absorption as you can have will help you. Do you have a bigger room to record in or do you need the isolation? You'll likely get better sonic results if you can find a room with some more volume... that will also allow you to play with position in front of the microphone. As far as the level you should record at, if you've got any half-decent mic pre than you can go into the computer pretty conservatively. Assuming you don't have a super noisy chain, there'll be plenty of headroom in a 24 bit recording to bring it up after the fact. If you're looking for numbers, I'd shoot to get things into your DAW at around -18 dBFS. Many of the plugins modeled after analog gear tend to be happier with that level (or less if you're unsure).

author: Eric Martin
content: I route my mix bus to a print bus and can use this as a ref A/B by toggling the input, then if I have a ruff mix or a ref I can choose the playlist of which one then I never process on a master, always mix bus process and print to the print bus, that way I can hear and SEE my mix getting printed in real-time as a check to make sure everything “looks” right as it sounds right

author: peterlabberton
content:
👆🏻 This room is a crazy steal in LA, good dudes in there as well! I just moved out of the room down the hall.

Regarding moving out of the central part of LA: I fucking love it so far. My girlfriend’s work is out on this side of the valley, which is what brought us here. We’re technically in Chatsworth, but our place is in a pocket of unincorporated weirdness in the hills. If it felt like suburbia I’d fucking off myself, but it feels like a small town in New Mexico. (Used to film westerns out here.) If my girlfriend didn’t have a great job with an awful commute from our old place, we wouldn’t have moved—until maybe several years down the road buying a house in, like, Altadena or something. But here we are! Now I just drive a lil longer to get to a show or a bar, whenever I go to one. 🤷🏻‍♂️ Long story short: LA (and greater LA) is huge and if you look around you can find loads of different options.

Also I’ll say I would NOT have wanted to live where I am now when I first moved here. Living in Los Feliz was awesome for being central and meeting people/getting my bearings, and LA being LA maybe there was some superficial bullshit cachet to being able to say I live in the cool part of town. I am less oriented to the pop world specifically, but Los Feliz/Silverlake/Echo Park/Highland Park/Atwater are all the places where the shit I think is cool and exciting happens. If anyone is considering a move to LA, I’d really recommend finding a place close to where the shows/people are that you’re interested in. Live there and rent for a while.

author: Slow Hand
content:
When did Spotify start defaulting to the "clean" version of tracks? I'm listening to this Baby Keem/Kendrick track right now and it's ruining it for me.

I recently re-listened to 'Blacks Reconstruction' by The Roots and it's completely unlistenable now that it has a good 80 edits in it, despite being labeled as the "Album Version": https://open.spotify.com/track/6cq1D3ZaL8SrrHkgHB8nwl?si=6720c9125a9e40b8

It's not as if records like this ever stood a chance of pop appeal and required an edited version to reach an audience. It's so dense with profanity that it'll never be played in public anyway. Now because of this censorship not only does it fail at being acceptable to a broad audience it's also rendered unlistenable to it's intended mature audience.

If I didn't already love this record and didn't already own an uncensored copy I almost certainly would never give it a fair listen and come to appreciate it. I can't help but wonder if a lot of great music today is being rejected out of hand and not discovered by new listeners because of the censorship.

author: Eric Martin
content:
I’m coming to an impasse; I’m in a band that works a lot and I record our stuff, and I get a lot of work Mastering and Mixing. The more I do that the more I realize that the production and tracking are significantly more important than MIX/MSTR for the “success of the song”.

I’d love to put my hands on outboard mastering gear but I have a few upgrades that I would like to do for my tracking situation(full live band tracking) and the costs are about the same for either, I get a little less work tracking but it’s like 40% Mastering 35% Tracking and 25% Mixing work.

Most mixes I do all in the box and the little outboard I have helps shape the tracking upfront and doesn’t get used in Mastering, but does get used sometimes in mixing.

I operate out of my home studio which provides low overhead, my “studio” is where my band rehearses and where I Mix and Master, I also bring bands in occasionally to track in my basement, but it a little tight.

I wonder what y’all’s thoughts are, I love doing all these things but feel like, I’m just kinda stuck treading water and not swimming toward a destination.

author: peterlabberton
content:
This Andrew Scheps podcast is fantastic. I’m not through this episode yet and I keep meaning to turn it off and get to work but, here I am, still at it. Highly recommended!

I was happy a few weeks ago to pick out a 16k tone ringing in a pretty big indie rock release that apparently never got caught in mixing or mastering. This was reassuring, but I know that I also definitely have a dip in the upper mids in my right ear—my guess is from years of drumming as a lefty, aka hihat on the right. In the last year or two I’ve always had a plug-in to flip left and right as the last step of my monitoring path that I can un-bypass to have a reality check. In addition to making sure there’s not an inappropriately loud guitar on the right, it’s just a great perspective shift.

author: Zack Hames
content: Do you have any way of recording at home? You mention "while you are not actually recording". The best way to practice is to literally do it as often as possible even if it's by yourself. You won't train the social aspect, you won't really train problem solving of an external source (a guitarist with a particularly shitty amp or playing technique per-say), but you can certainly experiment endlessly on capturing sounds. Shootouts, micing techinques, it's pretty much endless. If you don't have a recording setup at home or are in an apartment where you can't be as loud as you'd want, I try to absorb as much information as I can. Podcasts (Andrew Talks to Awesome People / Unstoppable Recording Machine / Working Class Audio / Conversations Audio), Online articles, (Sound on Sound) GearSpace Forum Q+A, TapeOp interviews, Youtube Series (Making Records with EV, Sounds-Like-a-Drum), etc. These can be incredibly inspiring and keep your mind tuned into the recording process.  I sort of use this as my "fix" when I am not able to work actively on a project. Otherwise, what everyone else has said about mixing are perfect suggestions. Maybe set limitations like only using plugins you haven't used. or remove a plugin you are constantly using to force yourself out of a habit. Practice editing dramatically even if the track doesn't call for it so you can get your editing chops up.

author: spectrummasters
content: Yeah bro @chris_donlin , so some people theorise that what people call the “cold “ sound of digital (as opposed to tape ) is that in nature we are never exposed to   a complete absence of sound . Only anechoic chambers provide that environment , so this is an unnatural sonic reality we begin composing in , in our DAWS . Obvs, analog emulation plug ins simply generate a little white noise to mimic the noise sound of real life electronic audio gear,  to trick us into the feeling of a more natural  ambience . author: 247amid
content: any1 know if i should use the high shelf eq on the neve 1073 with a  c800

author: ehutton21
content:
depends. if you’re running like a UAD situation, maybe don’t bother with the eq. that’s not really gonna give you real analog 

if you’re doing this outside the box with physical hardware, you can engage eq to shape the low end/mid range material if you want, and just not boost the hi shelf. in conventional analog neve EQs, there’s a transformer built into the EQ section which means leaving it engaged, even if the eq knobs are not doing anything, can impart more tone. that’s a nitpicky level thing considering this is a c800 into a 1073, but you never know—it might make a tonal difference to you/the talent being recorded.

author: Will Melones
content:
I can never STOP the scrolling with the magic mouse. All the flat stuff—Magic Mouse, trackpad—was killer on my wrist, and I never figured out exactly what the positioning and technique were with the trackball (sometimes even more painful for me than a mouse).

I’ve been using a vertical mouse for the last couple years, and it feels much more natural, and I’ve only had wrist pain on rare occasions. My only complaint is that the right hand has to make a higher jump over it to get to the keyboard.

author: Will Melones
content:
With the trackball I always feel the tendency to keep my hand in handshake position and roll it with my pinky anyway.

But maybe the biggest benefit to never leaving the house for the past two+ years has been not working at other people’s gigantic desks. My tabletop is *really* low, like elbows in my lap low. Someone taller than me wouldn’t be able to sit under it, but it’s very comfortable and relieves all the pinching and weird elbow/wrist contortions of a high work surface.

author: Slow Hand
content:
It seems trackpad is in the minority here, but I won't do anything else if I can help it:

1. No repetitive strain to speak of (anecdotal experience). Your hand floats and stays loose over the pad.

2. Can be placed right beneath the keyboard (if you're not already using a laptop) and cuts *way* down on travel time for your mousing hand as it travels from keys to mouse and back. It's always in the same place, so you never lose a moment of focus searching for the mouse with your eyes or adjusting your grip once you grab it, which adds up.

If you want to get *really* fancy you can press keys *and* use a trackpad with one hand in certain instances.

3. Multi-touch commands, bebe! (swipe, stretch, pinch, etc)

4. Can be ambidextrous if necessary.

author: ALXCPH

You don’t have to love the music, but if you hate every project you work on, I think burn out will be inevitable. I like the fact that you spun into a challenge and made it fun by using it as a way to learn even more. But let’s say you wanna be a mix engineer and work on hip hop. Red = ‘Needs resolution’ or ‘To Do’
Yellow = ‘In progress’ or ‘worth remembering’
Green = ‘Complete’ or ‘Final’

I rarely do this for individual files. It’s more for project folders like Ableton sessions. My *Song Sessions* folder is full of projects where I’m dicking around or doing a one-off thing and will never revisit, but if I sketch a song in an afternoon and it’s interesting enough that I may want to revisit it someday it’ll get a yellow dot so I can identify it as worth revisiting in the future.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Let the man sing if he wants to! 🤠 I’d argue that having some musical experience/intuition is 10/10 times not a bad thing. No matter what your job is in the music making process. 

Sure it’s not the engineers job to give advice. But if an artist asks when they are stuck with something being able to communicate at the same language is never a vibe breaker. I’d even argue it could enhance “vibes” or confidence, as long as what is being said makes contextual sense. 

It might be different where you are or at your level. But where I am (lower level 😂) who ever is in the room is involved. And if the process is being respected. I’ve been in so many sessions where I’ve recorded an artist and they ask for a harmony advice, or even if we are vocal producing, being able to quickly sing a line to quickly reference a point in the song is so much. Faster then having to look for it.

author: ehutton21
content:
To @Rollmottle’s point, maybe I can bridge this gap here, but from the perspective of someone dealing with mental health issues, it’s a fine line between empowerment and complete lack of accountability. There are ways of accommodating people that empower them, and that’s important. Part of that accommodation looks like recognizing that when someone has a really bad go, they’re going to struggle to assimilate themselves into the rest of society some days. But on the flip side, people with mental health issues are people. My bipolar ass can drive a car—doesn’t mean I get to drive off the road and cause collisions whenever I’d like, and even at my worst I’m capable of knowing that. 

Anxiety is difficult in that you often border on delusions—panic attacks are delusions about experiencing serious medical issues for a huge swath of people, and while that can make it difficult to do things like eat on a regular basis, I have to be mindful that having a stringent routine that keeps my triggers at bay is critical.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I can't stop thinking about this idea of "Why don't you play something that people actually like?"

I personally wrestle a lot with the idea of making music *for* other people. It's simply not very high on my list of priorities. I'd say I'm self-centered in how I approach making music. I'm out to make stuff that *I* want to hear. Things that aren't being represented elsewhere. Flavors I've never heard. I'm not aiming for a broad appeal, but I'm also not shying away from it. I'm just not much of a people pleaser in that regard. I'm in it for the discovery and the exploration and the pleasure of making something that excites me.

I think often about that Steve Jobs sentiment of "People don't know what they want until they see it." I think about that a lot. I trust that if I follow what feels good to *me* then I'll get something valuable out of it, and maybe it'll connect with others. If not, that's alright too. I'll know that I've made something that feels great.

I sometimes worry about this because I've always felt that it puts me at odds with a lot of people out here trying to make excellent records. Sometimes our goals will align, but I just don't feel motivated by the need to appeal to a lot of people and that can also make us diverge.

I guess what I'm trying to say is that there's a different kind of taste that I'm trying to cultivate. It's one that runs parallel to the kind of taste that is good at appealing to a large number of people. I feel as if I'm aiming at an entirely different goalpost from people playing the other game. I want to tickle people in a way that they didn't know they were capable of. That's what's thrilling to me.

author: BatMeckley
content:
There was this guitar store on myrtle Ave where I grew up, and I would ride my bike down there and just harass the owner 5 days a week. Would be that kid that tried every guitar and every amp.  And he would plug into something, and it would sound AWESOME, and then Id go and turn some knobs and play, and one time he just went “man, you’re able to dial your shitty tone in no matter what gear you plug into”, and I realized I had to figure out better what actually works… the shit that I was dialing in was kinda garbage. I think about that a lot. A lot of people have all the tools but still carve the same whack ass statue out of it.

But without counter to the status quo we’d never progress. There’s a line in there somewhere that I can’t quite figure out 5 martinis in.

author: peterlabberton
content:
Alright frens, seeking… wisdom? Advice? A gig? (Lol.)

I’ve wanted to live in nyc my entire adult life and never have—it’s never made sense to do it career-wise and probably never really will. But every time I’m there I feel totally at home and happy and excited in a way I don’t anywhere else. I spent a summer there several years ago and always linger as long as I can whenever I can, have close friends there (not in music), end up there usually a couple times a year and relish it every time. I feel like I know it as well as is possible for never having been a resident.

I know the music biz there is pretty much defunct (at least compared to LA), and I really *really* don’t want to repeat the emotional and financial ruin that I experienced moving to LA and restarting everything 6 yrs ago… but from a non-career perspective it’s where I want to be.

All that said, I’m in it to fucking win it in LA for my career—though with an eye for sure on getting to a point where I can relatively comfortably make that move.

Any wisdom/experience on making a mid-career move like this from folks here? I’m 35 yrs old, some decent credits but not major traction yet, in a basically married but not actually married relationship with a school principal who is into the idea of a move there as well (though our finances are totally separate and I for sure need to earn!), no kids or desire/plan to have kids.

Any benchmarks/goals that might be reasonable to aim for before seriously starting to make moves on this? I’d do it tomorrow if I could, but would also stay in LA for 5+ more years no prob to set things up properly. Even open to things like a podcast (/radio?/other audio prod) gig to help smooth the transition if that’s reasonable to find and lucrative enough—but what I’m really looking for is how to think of this as a full time freelance record maker. Or if someone on here secretly is hiring for staff gigs at Electric Lady, plz lmk 😉

author: BatMeckley
content: Also Rupert, bless the man’s legacy and soul, was 90 years old when the 500 series bae dropped…

author: David Fuller
content: most vintage neve stuff uses a single rail +24VDC supply, 500 series uses a 32V rail to rail bipolar supply. If you don't use the -16V rail, that's quite a bit less headroom than vintage...

author: BatMeckley
content: Also, to be clear, different doesn’t always mean worse… according to the smart dudes at chandler the 500 series tg2 is actually closer to the original console, though it is definitely different than the regular tg2.

author: David Fuller
content: sure - the OG 1073 etc runs on a single +24V DC rail. 500 series stuff uses a +16V and -16V rail, meaning you have effectively 32V to play with. As far as I understand it, you couldn't use a bipolar supply (+ and - rails) with that particular circuit design, so effectively you're dropping the supply voltage from +24V to +16V

author: David Fuller
content: correspondingly, you have about 4dB less range before you run into the supply rail and hard clip, never mind the onset of distortion as it gets closer to those voltage levels

author: David Fuller
content: for stuff that's *designed* for it, like API based designs, then it's great!

author: Deleted User
content:
Late to the discussion, but I do think the word ‘talent’ is reductive and oversimplification of one’s complex combinations of innate character/traits. A lot of little things coming together is what makes up the ‘innate talent’. Things that give certain people a head start on different crafts can probably be analyzed into different components. While “either you have it or you don’t” can lead to defeatist thinking, I believe seeing them as a make up of different components can really bring out individuals’ best self. 

we all have our fortes, but not everyone is able to break them down and integrate the different strengths to create synergy. And the “talented” individuals are the ones who has integrated the different strengths, whether it was through deliberate discoveries or something that was given to them circumstantially. I believe rephrasing ‘innate talent’ to something like ‘natural qualities/traits’ can lead to more freedom and more useful perspective than “I could never be like X” - because of course you can’t, you are not X. 

Which brings back to what you were saying about the value of  journey over the prize

author: Will Melones
content:
Shouldn’t they care to know? I’ve heard so many people in my family say they have no musical talent or they’re terrible at piano, but they’ve never practiced for 15 minutes. What’s the measurable difference between Yo-Yo Ma and your uncle?

My gut feeling is that most of talent comes down to commitment/focus (interest in the craft) and learning styles, and then culture and early exposure mold that into an affinity.

Some people will suck at an art form, put in the work, and then not suck anymore. Some will be born with a brain that’s wired to seeing shapes, and find it easy to visualize patterns on a guitar neck. Some will be auditory learners and may find it easier to learn to identify intervals by ear.

And then some people will grow up singing or playing in church, and those people get the cheat codes from a *very* young age while their brains are still spongey, learning things like their first language. Of course they weren’t born playing the organ, but it can look that way from the outside.

It seems both mystical and defeatist when people who don’t think they have talent talk about people who do—almost like an excuse. And maybe that’s intentional, and exactly the point you’re making.

TIP O my hat to the-electrical  engineers

author: spectrummasters
content: 😂 interesting reactions gents . Re rhe caps…..one of my goals is to be able to read a schematic for one of these and understand the physics and electrical processes at work . IMHO they are like a maze of genius . I’m caught up in the concept that electrical engineers were tapped into musical needs and concepts so much that they made legacy mysical momentd possible ( Ye olde Phil Collins SSL LMC drums scenario etc ) . Decades later in the digital world of an instant studio in a box, it’s not really obvious that some super bright tech came up with the routing ideas and then created the electrical circuitry for it . And then these techs would sort of partner the recording / mix engineers in a sort of perfect marriage of art and science . Love it !

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I did one season of a podcast with a friend who I love chatting with. 7 or so episodes and only one of them actually ended up mattering to me. 

Solid premise, thoughtful approach. Just didn’t work. What we needed was another 20 episodes to find a stride, to see what works. 

I really want to encourage you to lower the activation energy required for making a podcast if you really want to. Make it take as little time / energy as possible.

Dont plan trips to Boston before you’ve even started, cause then you’ll never start. Always ask the question “what would this look like if it were easy?”

In terms of software licenses, it can be software specific. Most softwares keep track of device ID so it will make you reset it while others have a dongle or key file you set the location to and it will follow over with you whenever you switch machines. 

Preferences - I don’t know how each plugins and software preferences work, but for the ones I use - I keep the shortcut files and presets. other than that, I try not to mess with preferences because I may have to trash them and start again at some point anyways.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
There are a lot of people who approach music as a business, and i think if I did I’d be more successful. 

Unfortunately for my family, I’ve always needed to love and believe in what I’m doing, but that prevents me from doing work that might be much more successful. I’ve pissed away a lot of opportunities because I don’t love the music. That felt like integrity when I was young, but in my 40s feels… more childish? 

I think finding things we don’t like in the way others do their business is an exercise in ego. Saying “I’d never do that” is less helpful than “I wonder why they do that.”

If you’ve spent your life building a template, and that template works at a very high level for high level clients, it makes sense you’d trust that. Same reason for playing live shows to click. Consistency is VERY tough to come by. 

Im not defending anyone, I don’t know the situation David was talking about, but I am suggesting that we be more curious, less judgmental.

I once had an ilok die the day I bought it and then another one died a month into me having it. After both of those happened I swore off ilok for while and friends swore to me that they never had a problem and said it must be user error. 

After some reading, it turned out that there was an undisclosed problem with bus-powered hubs killing them and I had been connecting them with a bus powered hub, so I gave ilok one more go and connected it straight to my mac and I haven’t had a problem in years

I also want to mention something I learned about recently, and that is borderline intellectual functioning. People with IQ between 71-84 are not categorized as disabled and you won’t notice them in everyday life, but it can be as common as 1 out of 7 people. They won’t be able to get a disability check, but will have harder time living than others with average or higher intelligence. 

It gave me a new perspective on why I can’t seem to communicate with or understand certain people, and that it needs to be approached with empathy whenever possible. 

+ poverty can affect people’s brain development. not only from the lack of education but the stress that goes on in the household due to poverty can affect children’s brain development. Truly unfortunate viscous cycle…

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
I had a fellow studio owner tell me one time that Dropbox changes audio in the files...   and guys,  I'm here to testify at the #nerd channel level:  that ain't true. Lol

But ...  user xp is crap and if that playback cause client conflict for you?  Kill it.  

Changing audio content though?  Not in my xp.  I'm partner in a sample library dev company, and we move about 25k to 50k samples per product through Dropbox.  Never has an artifact be "introduced" ...  it doesn't even effect metadata tags like iXML or bext. Certainly isn't changing a random sample in the PCM stream.

So, does anyone have strong feelings on home ownership?

Not sure where best to ask this, so I'll ask here:

What's the best way (or what are y'all doing) to make Spotify play back at the same level as your daw? 

I'm using an apollo for everything and I'd love to A/B things from a streaming service as I'm working on PT or Ableton. 

Spotify says turning its default to "loud" volume can compromise the sound quality, though I couldn't immediately find out what that means.

Will another streaming service do it? Do I need some extra interface or software? Why isn't this easy?

author: NoahNeedleman

Apollo over here, I have to have Apple Music volume down a touch or two to get levels right. It’s an infinitely variable slider so it’s inexact, but it’s mostly worked for me. 

Am I missing something important?

author: NoahNeedleman
content: That part I get; was wondering if there was a better way to do that via Apollo

author: Calvin Lauber
content: If you print your mix to a final stereo track, I will change the input of that track from whatever master bus output , to “MON L/R “ - which is the direct feed output of the Apollo. Then I mute that track and hit play on Apple Music (normalization off!) to print. I just record reference tracks straight in as part of the playlists of final mixes, that way when I’m in input mode I’m listening to my mix, and when I take it out I hear the reference. Instant A/B

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’m lossless on that for car/living room/cell phone

author: Adam Thein
content: Using Apple Lossless with soundcheck off over here.  Also be careful you have Spatial turned off (I believe it is on by default even on desktop).  I’ll record a loopback into the daw if I want to be able to consistently check against the same section.

author: masteredbyjack
content: Using Apple lossless with norm off as @Adam Thein + @Nomograph Mastering mentioned (EDIT: I listen day to day with the volume norm on, but when I need to hear a reference I listen with it off). Or when I find something I like I will buy the wav off Quboz and listen there in RX to compare (differences are very slight to me). I don't personally drag refs into sessions, again I'm only mastering, but the Quoboz wav would be perfect for that IMO (it seems to be the actual file released?)

author: jonmatteson

For Stagecoach & CMA Fest at Nissan Stadium, (haven’t played Coachella) they have a team that takes a 1 to 1 multi from our board and they mix for the live stream. It’s equivalent to having a house guy mix every band.

Mixing for the room & mixing for the stream are def 2 different things, but they really haven’t figured that shit out yet.

author: Matt Huber
content:
So, first of all, thanks to the buds here who appreciate what I’ve posted in the past.

Second of all, my thoughts on this:
 
I have a personal rule that I will NOT post anything that feels like EFFORT or out of a motivation to game the algo. If I’m “making content” and notice that I’m doing so out of a place that is less than genuine, I will just delete and move on. 

For me, the “mix tips” thing came out of a sincere place of excitement and passion. I would, as a growing mix engineer, stumble upon something that excited me, and I would find myself wanting to turn around to the people in the room to share…well, there’s almost never anyone in the room with me. So, I channeled that passion and excitement in a genuine way to share with the small community of mixers, mastering engineers and producers that I knew on IG. 

At the beginning of my career on to the middle of my career, that became a very fruitful source of business for me - people who followed me on IG, who enjoyed my posts, and began to view me as someone who MIGHT know a thing or two about mixing. 

As my career has developed and my clientele has growing, that has become less important, but it was absolutely pivotal in helping me build a deep bench of great clients, both indie and signed. 

But…I NEVER did it for that reason. It was always (and continues to be) a genuine result of my passion for what I do.

If you order a Gen 2 Orbit WITH electronic speed control (including Orbit Theory), then you will only need a standard step-down voltage transformer to use the turntable on voltages other than 120V. If you are using any Orbit WITHOUT electronic speed control, then you will instead need a frequency inverter to make sure the motor receives 60Hz power. author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
There’s scientific data on the regrets people have when dying. Not arguing anything with this (I’m squarely in the never satisfied camp) but it’s interesting in the context of this conversation. The top 5:

    1.    I wish I’d had the courage to live a life true to myself, not the life others expected of me.
    2.    I wish I hadn’t worked so hard.
    3.    I wish I’d had the courage to express my feelings.
    4.    I wish I had stayed in touch with my friends.
    5.    I wish I had let myself be happier.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
I was recently inspired after going to the cinema to see *A Complete Unkown*, the movie memoir about Bob Dylan; partially by Bob's story, but also by Timothy Chalomee's performance as Bob. All of the shots of him performing in the movie were fully live - which is an impressive feat by itself - but even more impressive that he apparently wasn't much of a musician before making the movie. I didnt know much about Timothy before this, so I watched his interview with Zane Lowe on Apple Music's YouTube channel. One thing I found really interesting was how available he made himself to learning the role. For example, he didn't turn his phone on for 3 months straight. Got me thinking about how much I can get distracted during the day, and how these distractions can get in the way of me actually giving 100% to the art that I'm working on. I'm sure you all can imagine how the distractions in your own life can effect your work. Might be TikTok videos, might be discord, might be lusting over getting new converters or monitors or guitars, etc, you get the idea. So I guess what I'm saying here is that if I want to compete with the best, maybe I have to understand how to impliment systems in my life that allows me to be more available to the things that I am working on. I want it to be like lifiting a heavy weight at the gym - at the bottom of a heavy squat, you've no choice but to focus on pushing the bar back up with good form, cos that think will break you otherwise. There's a certain thing that happens in your brain when you're forced to only think about one thing for a prolonged, or even short period. It's something akin to meditating. 

I guess what I'm asking is if anyone has ever given this subject any thought before, and if anyone has ever done anything to get better at these things? I'm still not sure if all this only makes sense inside my own head.

author: samvalentine
content:
Hey, I’m not sure where to post this exactly, but I had an interesting experience the other day that I’d like to share with the group and hopefully get some perspective on.

I was touching up a track with a producer friend at the end of a writing session. Vocals and guitar recorded over a 2track beat. I typically throw a Waves L2 on my master, just to bring up the level for the rough bounce, never doing much more than a dB or two of gain reduction. In this case I had the threshold of the L2 set at -3.4. The producer said try -3.5, then back to -3.4, then -3.5… flipping back and forth seeing what he liked more. I couldn’t hear a difference. (I should say that we weren’t in a well treated room, working on some mid sized genelecs. It’s a  setup neither of us is super familiar with.) He decided -3.4 was better and I was in disbelief that he could even hear a difference. I asked if I could do a blind test to see if he could tell which setting was which. He closed his eyes and I switched back and forth a bunch of times before landing on a setting, and he called it correct three times in a row. He said he could hear something in the kick drum but couldn’t explain more than that.
I need a sanity check. I know my ears aren’t hall of fame, but I’m still in disbelief that he was able to tell a .1dB difference in volume on the limiter.

author: kieronmenzies
content: Me personally, Yeezus was the last album that I was super moved by and I've never really had much of a desire to revisit any of his stuff, as brilliant as it is (though I might try after this convo). But on this topic, I find it hard/impossible to completely 100% enjoy a piece of work after the artist has done something disagreeable, taken a public downfall or occasionally if I had a negative personal experience with them. Even though I might intellectually appreciate the beauty of the work, my heart just feels a slight bit of ick -- akin to that feeling of trying to enjoy a meal that you know is super delish but you burned your tongue on a hot cup of coffee the day before. So I’ll just end up choosing to listen to something else instead. This also makes me intensely appreciate my past experiences with the art. I don’t think I’ll ever enjoy it the same way again but I’m so glad I was able to completely enjoy Puff Daddy productions, R. Kelly songs, Woody Allen’s movies, Bill Cosby’s comedy, and Kanye West’s early albums when they were coming out and having their day. I’m resolved that it was a time in my life and in the universe and that time might be over now. Kinda like the ex-girl that you remember fondly but would never ever ever go back to.

author: jerikcenteno
content:
Hey everyone, I'm pondering the idea of moving my studio out of my apt into a proper space. If you're in LA, what are some places that you have leased private lockouts/studios at? I've only come across Lemon Tree and had a friend at the lockouts at Kingsize. 

And then also a big question for anybody who's moved their set up out of their homes: Have you seen the ROI on moving your space out of your home/apt? I like the idea of moving my studio out because of the ability to have an artist/client come over without them being in my personal space. It wasn't that big of a deal to me when I was living alone and younger, but now that I'm getting a little older and living with my girlfriend, I grow less fond of the idea of people coming over to work. And if you did move out, did having that professional middle ground increase your business? 

I've never leased a studio before, but just a thought as life is moving along and I think I'll be able to lease a place! So, just wanted to see everyone's experience with this life and career move!

author: Brian Reynolds
content: It's anecdotal evidence my experience. The office space line is jest. But if true..... In this case. Even though you order all at once. They break it up. Into 95% in on order to be delivered in person. And two other items. All 3 charged to my card separately. The big order is to be delivered on a Friday so I could "complete over the weekend". They Never deliver it. Despite you sitting in an empty room. All day. Reading 14 automated messages over two days to be prepared. They said Monday. I had to be back to work Monday. And canceled for moral reasons. And sourced the materials thru a local lumber and rest from Lowes. Then got refunded two numbers that didn't match any I got charged. Started today looking for 284.71. Got back 155.15. Sales rep thought the only difference was the 89.99 they were still charging me for the delivery they never made. But that left me looking for 40 more. I had to spend 10 mins walking him thru the math. And that his subtotal wasnt what i got charged. So they coukd put it correct on a report. To Be pushed up the chain to a more senior person. Who will get back to me in 2 days with further details. Ooooofhfhhfhfhfhfhfhfhhfhfh. This is just a one off. But the math ain't mathing

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Yeah that makes sense. Thanks for the advice. The question is never ‘should I persist’ - Which is almost why I’m afraid. I feel like no matter what her and I are both locked in, and when someone else trusts me like that I want to be sure I can do my part in giving back in that dynamic.

It’s hard to weigh short term wins/losses vs long term wins/losses at this time cus I’m in the thick of it.

When reflecting, I know I always did my best to communicate as honestly as I could in every moment, and was transparent about every decision and my thought processes along the way. I’ve had many wins, but going a long period without financial wins has made me question the judgement I have when navigating everything.

“Winning” to me is a culmination of things that can be summed up as living authentically while positively contributing to the world and lives of others. It helps fight of the tendrils of negativity I feel coming from so many angles of the outside world, especially in the last decade.

I don’t exactly know what I’m asking. Or want. I’m looking to process these feelings and synthesize them into a new level of awareness as I move forward with what I’ve learned being integrated into my subconscious.

Sometimes being around others, or hearing their experiences and takes, helps me get angles of things in a way that I can piece together for a rough draft of what will become the lesson that I carry with me moving forward, regarding this topic at this time.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Very cool news today from Affinity. Today they've announced that their *Photo*, *Designer*, and *Publisher* programs have been merged into a single program *Affinity Studio*, and it's now free!

I've been using all of these programs as a low-cost, non-subscription alternative to the Adobe suite for years. They're less mature than Adobe's offering, but for my needs they're perfect, and continually improving. The fact that I can now switch between all three design modalities seamlessly is huge. It's like having *Photoshop*, *Illustrator*, and *InDesign* in the same program, without the need to export/import between each of them. From a workflow standpoint that is *huge*.
https://www.affinity.studio/get-affinity

author: popthetrunk
content:
You can’t boot a drive you use as a Time Machine backup directly as in the past. 

But you can make an external disk bootable by installing macOS to an APFS disk via the regular installer or from macOS Recovery. 

You could then restore a Time Machine backup to this bootable disk, and then boot your restored OS.

On Apple Silicon the install needs to be done from a port other than the device firmware update(DFU) port, easy to look up which one for your model. But you can boot from any port after. You’ll need to change the security mode in the Startup Security Utility on the machine you are booting to Reduced Security, also just enable kernel extensions while you are there if you need for an interface like UAD etc.

This bootable OS will be specific to your Mac Model, as in, a m4 mbp installed external will not boot an m2 Mac mini or an m5 mbp etc. I’m not sure if it needs to be the same specs, but that could easily be tested
